div.l: When that Aprill with his shoures sote
The drought of March had perced the rote
And bathed euery vaine in soche licoure
Of which vertue engendred is the floure
When Zephirus eke with his sote breth
Espired hath euery holte and heth
The tendre croppes and the yong sonne
Hath in the Ram halfe his course yronne
And smale foules maken melodie
That slepen all night with open eye
So priketh hem nature in her courage
Than longen folke to go on pilgrimage
And palmers to seken straunge strondes
To serue halowes couthe in sondrie londes
And specially fro euery Shires ende
Of Englonde to Canterbury they wende
The holy blisful Martyr for to seke
That hem hath holpen when they were seke .
YT befell that season on a day
In Southwarke at the Taberd as I lay
Redie to go in my pilgrimage
To Canterbury with deuoute courage
That night was come into that hostelry
Well nine and twenty in a company
Of sondrie folke by auenture yfall
In feliship / and pilgrimes were they all
That toward Canterbury wolde ride
The chambres and stables weren wide
And well weren they eased at the best
And shortly whan the sonne was at rest
So had I spoken with hem euerychone
That I was of her feliship anone
And made forward early for to rise
To take our way ther as I you deuise
But netheles while I haue time and space
Or that I further in this tale pace
Me thinke it accordaunt to reason
To tell you all the condicion
Of eche of hem so as it semed me
And which they were / of what degre
And eke in what araye that they were in /
And at a knight then will I first begin .
A knight there was ⁊and that a worthie man
That fro the time that he first began
To riden out / he loued Cheualrie
Trouthe / honoure / fredome and curtesie
Full worthy was he in his Lordes warre
And thereto had he ridden no man so farre
As well in Christendome as in Hethinesse
And euer had honoure for his worthinesse
At Alisaundre he was when it was won
Full ofte time he had the bourde begon
Abouen all nations in Pruce
In Lettowe had he ridden and in Luce
No christen man so ofte of his degree
In Garnade at the siege had he be
Of Algezer / ⁊and riden in Belmarie
At Leyes was he / and also at Satalye
Whan they were wonne / ⁊and in the great see
At many a noble armye had he be
At mortall batailles had he ben fiftene
And foughten for our faith at Tramissene
In listes thries and aye slaine his foe
This ilke worthie knight had ben alsoe
Somtime with the Lord of Palathie
Ayenst another Hethen in Turkie
And euermore he had a soueraine prise
And though he was worthie he was wise
And of his sporte as meke as is a maide
He neuer yet no vilanye ne saide
In all his life / vnto no maner wight
He was a very perfite gentil knight
For to tell you of his araye
His horse were good / but he was nothing gaye
Of fustyan he wered a gippon
All besmottred with his Haubergion
For he was late come fro his viage
And wente for to done his Pilgrimage
With him ther was his sonne a yong squire
A louer and a lustie Bachelere
With his lockes crull as they were laid in presse
Of twenty yere of age he was as I gesse
Of his stature he was of euen length
And wonderly deliuer and of great strength
And he had be somtime in chiuauchie
In Flaundres / in Artois / and in Picardie
And borne him well / as of so litel space
In hope to stande in his Ladies grace
Embroded was / as it weren a mede
All ful of freshe flowres / white and rede
Singing he was / or floiting al the daye
He was freshe as is the moneth of Maye
Short was his gowne / with sleues long ⁊and wide
Wel coude he sitte on a horse and fayre ride
He coude songes make / and wel endite
Iuste and eke daunce / portray and wel write
So hote he loued / that by nighter tale
He slept no more then doth a Nightingale
Curteis he was / lowly and seruysable
And kerfte before his Fader at the table .
A Yeoman had he and seruauntes no mo
Al that time / for him liste to ride so
And he was clad in cote and hode of grene
A shefe of Pecocke arowes bright ⁊and shene
Vnder his belt he bare ful thriftely
Wel coude he dresse his tackle yomanly
His arowes drouped not with fethers lowe
And in his hand he bare a mightie bowe
A notte heed had he / with a browne visage
Of wodde crafte / wel couth he al the vsage
Vpon his arme he bare a gay bracer
And by his side a swerde and a bokler
And on that other side a gay daggere
Harneised well / and sharpe as pointe of spere
A Christofer on his brest of siluer shene
An horne he bare / the baudricke was of grene
A foster was he southly as I gesse
There was also a None a Prioresse
That of her smiling was simple ⁊and coye
Her greatest othe was by saint Loye
And she was called dame Eglentine
Ful wel she song tho seruice deuine
Entewned in her voice ful semely
And french she spake ful fetously
After the scole of Stratforde at Bowe
For Frenche of Paris was to her vnknowe
At meate was she well ytaught with all
She let no morsel fro her lippes fall
Ne wete her fingers in her sauce depe
Wel couth she cary a morsel and wel kepe
That no drop ne fel vpon her brest
In curtesy was set ful moche her lest
Her ouerlip wiped she so clene
That in hir cuppe was no ferthing seene
Of grece whan she had drunke hir drauhte
Ful semeli after hir mete she rauhte
And sikerli she was of grete disport
Of plesaunce and ameable of port
And peyned hire to countirfete chere
Of court to be stateli of manere
And to beholden digne of reuerence
But for to speke of hir conscience
She was so cheritable and so couetous
She wolde wepe if she se amous
Caught in a trappe if it were ded or bledde
Of smale houndes had she þat she fedde
With roste flesshe and wastelbrede
But sore wepte she if any of hem were dede
Or if men smot hem with a yerde smert
And al was conscience and tender herte
Ful semeli hir wimpel pynched was
Hir nose streight hir eien grey as glas
Hir mouþe smal and therto softe and rede
But sikerli she had a faire forhede
It was almost a span brood I trowe
For hardli she was nat vnder growe
Ful fetise was hir cloke as I was ware
Of smal coral aboute hir arme she bare
A peire of bedis gauded al with grene
And theron henge abroche ful shene
On whiche first was writen a crouned A .
And after that amor vincit omnia
An other None / wᵗith hir had she
That was hire chapelyn and prestes thre
A monke that was faire for the maistrie
And an outrider he loued venerie
A manli man to be an Abbot able
Ful many deynte hors had he in his stable
And when he rood men might his bridel hiere
Gingling in whistling winde clere
And eek as loude as doþ the chapel belle
There as the lorde was keper of the selle
The reule of seint Maury or of seint Benet
Because it was olde ⁊andsomdel streit
This ilke monk let olde þīmges pace
And hielde after the newe worlde þe space
He yeaff not of the text a pulled henne
That seith that hunters be nat holi men
Ne that amonk whan that he is recheles
Is likned to a fisshe whan þat he is waterles
That is to sei amonk out of acloister
But that text held he not worth an oister
And I seide þᵗat his opinion is good
What sholde he studie / and make him wood
Vpon abook in cloistre alwai to poure
Or swinke wᵗith hondis and laboure
As austen bit but how shal the world be serued
Let austen haue his swinke to him reserued
Therfore he was a pkasour aright
Grehoundes he had as swifte as foule in flight
Of priking and of hunting for the hare
Was al his lust for noþing wol he spare
I sawe his sleuis purfled at the hande
With grys and that finest of a londe
And for to fastin his hood vnder his chinne
He had of gold wrought a corious pynne
Aloue knotte in the gretter ende was
His heed was balled and shon as glas
And eek his face as he had ben anoynte
He was a lord fatte and in good poynte
His eien stepe and rolling in his heed
That stemed as a furnes of a leed
His botis soupil his hors in gret astate
Now certeinly he was a faire prelate
He was nat pale / as a forpined goste
A fatte swanne loued he best of eny roste
His palfreie was as broun as berie
A frere therwas a wanton and a merie
A lymytoᵘur and a ful solempne man
In al the ordres foure is noon that so wel can
So moche of daliaunce and so faire language

l.hi: He had made many a faire mariage

div.l: Of yonge women at his owne coste
Vntoo his ordre he was anoble poste
And welbeloued and ful famulier was he
Wᵗith frankleyns oueral in his contre
And wᵗith worthi yomen of the toun
For he had power of confessioıı̄un
And ful sweteli herde he confessioıı̄un
And plesaunt was his absolucioıı̄un
And seide himself more than a curate
And of his ordre he was licenciate
Was verrei felicite parfite
Þat helde opinion that plein delite
An housholder and that agret was he
Curteis also and eek / fre
An esi man to yeue penaıı̄unce
There he wist to haue good petaıı̄unce
Vnto a poore ordre for to yeue
Is signe that aman is wel I shreue
If he yaff he durst / make auaunt
He wist that aman was repentaunt
Many man so harde is of herte .
Mai nat wepe if he soore smerte
Therfore in stede of weping and pᵃiers
Mēm muste yeue siluer to þe poore freres
His tippet was stuffed ful of knyues
And with pinnes to yeue faire wiues
And certeinli he had a meri note
Merili coude he singe and pleie at the rote
Of tidinges he bar vtterli the pris
Milke white he was as þe floure delis
Therto stronge he was as a champion
He knewe the tauernes wel in eủer/rey toun
And eủer/rey hosteler and tapster
Better than a laser or a begster
For as to suche a man as he .
Accordeþ nat as bi his faculte
To haue wᵗith such sik lasers aqueyntaıı̄unce
It is nat honest it mai nat auaıı̄unce
For to dele with such poraile
Al wᵗith riche and sellers of vitaile
And oueral ther as richesse shuld arise
Curteis he was and louli of seruise
Ther was noman nowher so vertuous
He was þe best begger in his hous
For ther a widow had not a sho
So plesaunt was in principio
Yitt wolde he haue a ferthing or he wente

l.hi: His purchas was better than his rente

div.l: And barke he couþe as it were a whelpe
In loue daies . ther couþe he moche helpe
For there he was nat lik a cloisterer
Wᵗith a thredebare cope as a poor frere
But he was lik amaist̉er/re or a pope
Of double worsted was his semeli cope
That rounde was as abelle out of presse

l.hi: Somwhat he lisped for his wantonesse

div.l: To make his englissh swete on his tonge
And his harping when that he had songe
His eien twincled on his heed aright
As doon the sterres / in þe frosti night
This worthi limitoᵘur was called huberd
A marchaıı̄unt þ̉er/rewas wᵗith a forked berd
In motteley on hihe on hors he satte
Vpon his heed a flaundres bever // hatte
His botis clapsid / faire and fetousli
His resons he spak ful solempneli
Shewyng alwai þencres of his wynnyng
He wolde the see were kepte for eny thinge
Betwixt Middelburgh and orwel
Wel coude he in his eschaıı̄unge sheldes selle
This worthi man his witt ful wel besette
Ther wist nowight what he was in dette
So stateli was he of gouernaunce
Wᵗith his bargayns and wᵗith his cheuisaıı̄unce
Forsothe he was aworþi man wᵗithall
But soth to sei I not how men him calle
A clerk ther was of Oxinforde also
That onto logique long had I go
And lene was his hors as is a rake
And he was nat right fatte I vndertake
But loked holow and therto sobirli
Full thredbare was his oủer/reeste courtepi
For he had gete him right no benefice
Ne was nat worþi to haue an office
For him was leuer to haue at his beddes heed
Twenti bokis cled in blak and reed
Of aristotle and of philosophie
Than robis riche or fidel or sautrie
But albe that he was a philosophre
Yitt had he but litel gold in cofre
But al that he might of his frendis hente
On bokis and on lernyng he it spent
And besili gan for the soules praie
Of hem þat gaff hem wherwith to scolaie
Of studie took he most cure and hede
Nat oo worde spak he moor þan nede
Short and quik was he of sentence
Sownyng / in moral vertu was his pʳdence
And gladli wolde he lerne ⁊and gladli teche
And therto fulsofte was he in his speche
A sargeaıı̄unt of lawe war and wise
That often had ben at the parvise
That also was riche of excellence
Discrete he was and of gret reuerence
He semed suche his wordes were so wise
Iustise he was fulofte att assise
Bi patent and bi plein cōmmissioıı̄un
For his science and his high renoıı̄un
Of fees and robes had he many oon
So gret a purchasoᵘur was þ̉er/re never noon

l.hi: Al was fee simpel to him in effect

div.l: His purchas might not be to him suspect
Nowher so leef aman as he ther nas
And yitt he semed besier than he was
In termys had he cas and domys alle
That fro the time of king william wer falle
Therto he coude endite and make athing
Ther couthe nowight pinche at his writing
And eủer/rey statute coude he plein bi rote
He rood but homeli in a myddel cote
I gird wᵗith a seynt of silke wᵗith barres smale
Of his arrai telle I no lenger tale
A frankelein was in his companye
Whit was his berd as is the daisie
And of his complexioıı̄un . he was sanguyn
Wel loued he bi þe morwe a cuppe of wyn
To liue in delite was euer his wone
For he was epiourue owne sone
That hield opinioıı̄un / that plein delite
Was verrai felicite parfite
An housholder / and þat a gret was he
Seint Iulian he was in his cuntre
His bred his ale was euer after oon
A better ēmvined man was ther noon
Without bake metis was he neủer/re in his hous
His fisshe his flessh and þat so plenteuous
It shewed in his hous of mete and drinke
Of al deintees þat men couthe thinke
After the sondri ceson of the yere
So chaungeþ he his mete and his souper
Full many a fatte partrik had he in mewe
And many a breme and luce in stewe
Wo was his cook but his sauce were
Poynaıı̄unt and sharp and redi al his gere
His table dormant in his halle alwai
Stood redi couered al the long dai
At cessions ther was he lord and sire
Fulofte time was he knight of þe shire
A lace and a gisper of silke
Heng at his girdel whit asmorow milke
A shereff had he be and a coronoᵘur
Was nowher suche aworthi vauasoᵘur
An haberdassher and a carpenter
A Webbe a diere and a tapiser
And thei were clothed al in oo liuere
A solempne and agret fraternite
Ful fressh and newe here gere apiked was
Hir knyues wer chaped not with bras
But al with siluer wrought ful clene and wele
Her knyues and her poaches eueridele
Wel semed hem eche a faire burgeis
To sitte at the yelde halle at the deis
Euerich for the wsdam that he can
Was happeli for to be an Alderman
For catel had thei Inough and rente
And her wyues wolde it wel assente
And ellis certein thei were to blame
It is ful feire to be called madame
And go to vigilies al before

l.hi: And haue amantel rialli bore

div.l: A cook thei had with hem for the nonys
To boile the checons wᵗith the mari bonys
And pouder marchaıı̄unt tart and galingale
Wel coude he knowe a draught of london ale
He coude roste . sethe . boile and frie
Make mortrewes and wel make a pie
But gret harme was it as it thought me
For on his shene amormal had he
For blāmk manger made he with the beste
A shipman ther was þat woned fer be weste
For ought I woot he was of dertmouthe
He rood vppon a rouncy as he couthe
In agowne of folding to the kne
Adagger on a lace hanging had he
Aboute his necke vnder his arme adoune
The hoot somer had made his hewe al broune
And certeinli he was agood felawe
Full many a draught wine had he drawe
Fro burdeuxward whiles the chapman sleep
Of nice conscience took he no keep
At ful many batel in þat londe
He faught and had the higher honde
But of his crafte to reken wel his tides
His stremys and his daıı̄ungers him besides
Ther was non suche from Hulle vnto Cartage
For wise he was þough he wer ful of corage
Hardi he was and war to vndertake
With many a tempest his berde hath I quake
He kneuh al the hauenes as þei were
Fro Inglond into Capfenester
And eueri creek in bretein and in spaine
His barge was called the Magdaleine
WIth vs ther was a doctoᵘur of phisique
In al the worlde ther was noon him liek
To speke of phisique and of surgerie
For he was grounded in Astronomie
He kept his pacience a ful gret dele
In houres bi magique naturele
Wel couthe he of fortune the accident
Of his Image for he is pacient
He kneuh the cause of eueri maladie
Whether it were of colde moist hete or drie
And where engendred and of what humoᵘur
He was a verrai parfit practisour
The cause he kneuh and of his harm the rote
Anoon he yaff the seke man his bote
For redi he is a poticaries
To sende him dreggꝭes and his lectuaries
For eche of hem made other for to wynne
Her frendship was nat newe to begynne
Ful wel kneuh he the olde escalapius
And discorides and eke Rufus
Of olde Ipocras hali and eek Galiene
Serapion Razie / / and eek avisene
Auerois damastien and custantyn
Bernard gatisden and gilbertyn
Of his diete mesurable was he
For it was of noon suꝑper/parfluite
But of gret norishing and degestible
His studie was but litel on the bible
In sanguyn and in perce / / clad withal
I lyned with taffata and with sendal .
And yitt he ne was but esi of dispense
He kept that he wan in pestilence

l.hi: For gold in phisik is a cordial

div.l: Therfor he loued gold in special
A good wiff ther was beside bathe
And she was somdel deff and þᵗat was skathe
Of cloth making / had she suche an haunte
She passed hem of Ipris and of gaunte
In all the parissh wiff was þ̉er/re noon
That to the offring afore hire shulde goon
And if þanne certein wroth was she
Thanne was she out of al cherite
Hir kerchers ful fine were of grounde
I durst seie thei weied doun apounde
That on a sondai were on hire heed
Hire hosen were of fine scarlet reed
Ful streight I teide and shois ful newe
Bold was hir face feir and reed of hewe
She was a worþi woman al hir lyue
Husbondis at chirchedore had she fiue
Without oþer company in youþe
But therof nedeþ not to speke as nouthe
And þries had she ben and at Ierusaleme
She had passed many straunge streme
At Rome had she ben and at Babilonye
In Galis att seint Iames and at colie
She couthe moche of wandring on the waie
Gappetothed was she sothli for to seie
Vpon an ambeler ful eseli she satte /
I wimpled wel / and on hir heed an hatte
As brode as it were abokelere or a targe
A foot mantel aboute hir hippis large
Vpon hir helis a peire of sporis sharpe
In felauship couthe she laughe and carpe
Of remedies of loue she couthe pʳchaunce
For of that arte she couthe the daunce /
A good man ther was of Religioıı̄un
And was a pouer ꝑper/parson of a toun
But riche he was and holi of werk /
He was also a lerned man a clerk /
That cristis gospell treuli wolde preche
His parisshens deuoutli wolde he teche
Benigne he was and wonder diligent
And in aduersite ful pacient
And suche he was proued ofte sithes
Ful lothe wer he to curse for his tithes
But rather wolde he yeue out of doute
Vnto his poủer/ree ꝑper/parisshens rounde aboute
Of his offring and of his sustenaıı̄unce
He couþe in litel thinge haue suffisaunce
Wide was his ꝑper/parisshe / and houses fer asonder
But he let not for rayn ne thonder
In sikenesse nor in myschef to visite
The ferthest in the ꝑper/parisshe more and lite
Vpon his feet and in his honde a staffe
This noble ensample to his sheep he yaffe
That first he wrought and aftirward he taught
Out of the gospel the wordis he caught
And this figure he added eek thertoo

l.hi: That yf gold rust what shold Iren doo .

div.l: For if a prest be foule in whom we truste
No wonder if that a lewed man ruste
And shame is it if a prest take kepe /
A shiten shepherd and a clene shepe
Wel ought a prest ensampil for to yeue
Bi his clennesse how his sheep shulde liue
Beset not his benefice to hire
And lete his sheep acombren in the mire
And renne / / to london to seint paulis
To seken him a chauntrie for saulis
Other wᵗith abrotherhed to be holde
But duelling at home to kepe his folde
So that þe wolf ne had nat miscarie
He was a shepherde and nat a mercenarie
And though he holi were and vertuous
He was to sinful men nat to dispetous
But in his speche discrete and benigne
Ne of his speche daungerous ne digne
To drawe folk to heuene wᵗith fairenesse
Bi good ensampil this was his besinesse
But it were any ꝑper/parson obstinat
How so were he highe or lowe of state
Him wolde he / snebbe for the nonys
A bettre prest I trowe þᵗat nowher non is
He waited after no pompe ne reuerence
Ne made him no spiced conscience
But cristis lore and his apostolis twelue
He taught but first / he folowed hem selue
WIth him ther was a ploman was his brother
Þat had Ilad of dong many a fother
A trewe swinker and a good was he
Lyuyng in pees and in parfit charite
God loued he wel with al his hert
At al times though he gamed or smert
And than his neighbourgh right as him selue
He wolde thresshe and therto digge and delue
For cristis sake for eueri poer wight .
Without hier if it lai in his might
His tithes paied he ful faire and wel
Bothe of his ꝓpropre swynke and his catel
In a tabard he rood vpon a mere
Ther was also a Reue and a mellere
A sompnoᵘur and a pardoner also
A maunciple and my selue ther were namo
The mellere was astout carle for the nones
Ful big he was of brawne and of bones
That preued wel / for oueral where he cam
At wrastling he wolde haue awaie the ram
He was short shuldred a thikke knarre
Ther was no dore þat he ne wolde heue of harre
Or breke it at a rennyng wᵗith his heed
His berd as any sow or fox was reed
And therto brood as þough it were a spade
Vpon the cop right of his nose he hade
A wert and theron stood a tuft of heris
Reede as the brestles of a sowes eris
His noise thrilles blak were and wide
A swerde and bokeler bar he bi his side
His mouthe as grete was as agret fourneis
He was a Iangeler and a galiardeis
And þat was most of sinne and harlotries
Wel couthe he stele corn and tolle thries
And yitt he hadde athombe of gold parde
A whight cote and blewe hood wered he
A bagge pipe wel couþe he blowe and sowne
A therwithal he brought vs out of toun
A gentil maunciple was þ̉er/re of a temple
Of which actatours might take example
For to ben wise in bieng of vitaile
For whether he paied or took / bi taile
Algate he waited so in his achate
That he was aie beforn and in good state
Now is nat that of god a ful faire grace
That suche alewed mannes witt shal pace
The wisdam of an heep of lerned men
Of maistres had he moo þan thries ten
That were of lawe expert and corious
Of which ther was a doseyn in that hous
Worthi to ben stiwardes of rent and londe
Of any lorde that is in Ingelonde
To make him lyue bi his ꝓpropre good
In honoᵘur detles but if that he were wood
Or liue as scarsli as hym list desire
And able for to helpen al a shire
In any cas that might falle or happe
And yett this manciple sette here al þ̉er/ree cappe
The Reue was a sklender colerik man
Hes berde was shaue as nigh as eủer/re he can
His heer was bi his eris ful rounde I shorne
His toppe was dokked lik a prest bi forne
Ful longe were his leggis and ful lene
I lik a staff ther was no calf I sene
Wel couþe he kepe agarner or a bynne
Ther was noon auditoᵘur couþe on him wynne
Wel wiste he bi the drouhte and bi the reyn
The yelding of his seed and of his greyn
His lordis shepe his nete his daierie
His swyn his hors his stoor and his pulletrie
Was hooli in this reues gouernynge
And bi his couenaıı̄unt gaf the rekenynge
Sin that his lord was twenti yer of age
Ther couþe noman bring him in arrerage
Ther was bailif ne herde ne other hyne
That he ne knewe his sleiht and his covyne
Thei were a drad of him as of the deth
His wonyng was ful fair vpon an heth
With grene trees shadwed was his place
He couþe better thanne his lorde pʳchace
Ful riche he was astored pⁱriueli
His lord he couthe wel plesen subtili
To yeue and lene him of his owne good
And haue a thanke and yett acote and a hode
In youthe he hed lerned awel good mistere
He was awel good wright a carpentere
This Reue sat vp on a ful good stot
That was al pomeli grey and hight scot
A longe surcote of peers vpon he hadde
And bi his side he barre a rusti bladde
Of northfolk was this Reve of which I telle
Besiden atoun men clepe it Baldeswelle
Tukked he was as is a frere aboute
And euer he rood the hindrest of oure route
A sompnoᵘur was þ̉er/re wᵗith vs in that place
That had a firy cherubynnes face
For sauceflem he was with eien narwe
As hoot he was and lecherous as a sparwe
With scalled browes blak and piled berde
Of his visage children were afferde
Ther nas quyk silủer/relitarge or bremston
Boras orsure ne oile of tartre noon
Ne oynement that wolde clense and bite
That him might helpe of his whelkes white
Nor of the knobbes sitting in his chekes
Wel loued he garlik oynons and eek lekes
And for to drinke stronge wyn red as any bloode
Than wolde he speke and crie as he were woode
And whan þat he wel dronken had þe wyne
Than wolde he speke noworde but latyne .
A fewe termes had he two or thre
That he had lerned out of som decre
No wonder is he herde it al þe dai

l.hi: And eek ye knowen it wel how that a Iai

div.l: Can clepe watte aswel as can the pope
But who so couþe in other thinge him grope
Than had he spent al his philosophie
Ay questio quid iuris wolde he crie
He was agentil harlot and a kinde
A better felawe shul men not finde
He wolde suffre for a quart of wyne
A good felawe to haue his concubyne
A twelue monthe and excuse him at fulle
Ful priueli a finche eek couþe he pulle
And if he fonde owher a good felawe
He wolde techen him to han noon awe
In swiche caas of the Archedeken curs
But if mannes soule were in his purs
For in his purs he shulde punshed be

l.hi: Purs is þe Archedekenes helle seide he

div.l: But wel I woot he lied right in dede
Of cursing ought eche gilti man him drede
For curs wol sle right as asoiling sauith
And also war him of a significauith
In daunger had he at his owne gise
Tho yonge gerles of þe diocise
And knew hire counsail and what was al hir rede
A garland had he sette vpon his hede
As grete as it were for an ale stake
A bokeler had he made him of a kake
WIth him ther rood agentil ꝑper/pardoner
Of Rouncyual . his frende and his comper
That streight was comen fro þe court of rome
Ful lowde he songe / come hider loue tome
This sompnoᵘur bar to him a stif burdoıı̄un
Was neuer trompe of half so gret a sown
This pardoner had heer as yellow as wax
But smothe it henge as doþ a strike of flax
Bi ounces henge his lokkes þat he hadde
And therwith he his shuldernes ouerspradde
But thinne it lai bi culpons oon and oon
But hood for Iolite wered he noon
For it was trussed vp in his walet
Him thought he rood al of the newe get
Discouered sauf his cap he rood al bare
Such glaringe eien had he lik an hare
A vernacle had he sowid on his cappe
His walet biforn him in his lappe
Bret ful of ꝑper/pardon comen fro rome al hote
A vois he hadde as smal as agote
No berde ne had he / ne neủer/re shulde haue
As smoþe it was as it were late shaue
I trowe he were a gelding or a mare
But of his craft fro berwik in to ware
Ne was ther swich anoþ̉er/reꝑper/pardoner
For in his male he had a pilowber
Which that he saide was oure ladi vaile
He seide he had a gobet of þe saile
That seint petir had whan þat he went
Vpon the see til Ihıı̄un crist him hent
He had a crois of laton ful of stones
And in a glas he had pigges bones
But with thise reliques whan þat he fonde
A poure ꝑper/parson duelling vpon þe londe
Vpon a dai he gat him more moneye
Than þᵗat þe ꝑper/parson gat in monethes tweye
And þus wᵗith feined flatring and Iapes
He made the ꝑper/parson and þe peple his apes
But treuli to tellen atte laste
He was in churche anoble ecclesiaste
Wel couthe he rede a lesson or a stori
But alderbest he song an offertori
For wel he wist whan þat songe was songe
He most preche and wel affile his tonge
To wynne siluer as he wel coude
Therfore he songe so merili and loude
Now haue I tolde you sothli in a clause
The estate þe nombre the arrai and eek þe cause
Whi that assembled was this companye
In southwerk / at this gentil hosterie
That hight the tabert fast bi the belle
But now is time to you for to telle
How that we beren vs that ilke night
Whan we were in þat hosterie a light
And after wol I tellen of oure viage
And al the remenaıı̄unt of oure pilgrimage
But ferst I preie yow of youre curtesie
That ye ne rette it noght my vilanye
Thouh that I pleinli speke in þis matere
To tellen here wordes and here chere
Ne though I speke here wordes ꝓpropurli
For this ye knowen as wel as I /
Who so shal tellen a tale after aman
He moot reherce as nigh as euer he can
Euerich worde if it be in his charge
Al speke he neủer/re so rudeli and large
Or elles he moot telle his tale vntrewe
Or feyne thinges and finde wordes newe
He may not spare although he were his brothir
He mot also seie as wel o worde as another
Crist spak himsilf / ful brode in holi writ
And wel ye woot no velenye is itte
Eek plato seiþ who so can him rede
The wordes mot be cosynne to the dede
Also I praie you forgeue it me
Al haue I not set folk in her degre
Here in this tale as þat thei sholde stonde
Mi witte is short ye mai wel vnderstonde
GRete chere made oure ost vs euerichone
And to the soper sette he vs anoon
He serued vs with vitailes at the beste
Stronge was the wyn and wel drinke vs leste
A semeli man oure ost was wᵗithall
For to ben amarchal in an hall
A large man he was with eien stepe
A fairer burgeis is noon in chepe
Bolde of his speche and wis and wel I taught
And of manhode him lakked right naught
Eek þerto he was right a meri man
And after soper pleien he bigan
And spak of mirthe among oþ̉er/re thinges
Whan that we had made oure rekenynges
And seide thus now lordinges treuli
Ye ben to me welcome right herteli
For bi mi trouþe if þat I shal nat lie
I see not this eer so meri a companye
Atonys in this herberwe as is now
Fain wolde I don you mirþe wist I how
And of a mirþe I am right now be þought
To don you ese and it shal cost nought
YE gon to Cauntirbury god you spede
The blisful martir quyte yow yoᵘur mede
And wel I woot as ye goon bi the weie
Ye shapen you to talen and to pleie
For treuli comfort ne mirthe is noon
To riden bi the weie dombe as a stoon
And þerfore wol I maken you disport
As I seide erst and don you som comfort
And if you like alle bi oon assent
For to stonden at my Iugement
And for to werken as I shal you seie
To morn whan we riden bi the weie
Now bi my fader soule þat is ded
But ye be mery I wil yeue you my hed
Holde vp yoᵘur handes without more speche
Oure counsaile was nat longe for to seche
Vs þought it was nat worth to make it wis
And graunted him without more auys
And bad him seie his verdit as him leste
Lordinges qd . he now herkeneþ for the beste
But take it not I praie you in disdeigne
This is the point to speke short and pleigne
That eche of you to short wᵗith oure weie
In this viage shal telle tales tweie
To Cantirburyward I mene it so
And homwardes he shal telle other two
Of auentures that whilom haue befalle
And which of you þat bereþ him best of alle
That is to sein that telleþ in this caas
Tales of best sentence and most solaas
Shal haue a soper at oure aldercost
Here in þis place sittyng bi this post
Whan þat we come ageyn from Cantirbury
And for to make you the more mery
I wil my self goodli wᵗith you ride
Right at myn own cost and be yoᵘur gide
And who so wol my Iugement withseie
Shal paie al þat we spende bi the weie
And if ye vouchesaf that it be soo
Tel me anoon wᵗithout wordes moo
And I wol erli shape me þerfore
This thing was graunted and oure othes swore
With glad hert and praien him also
That he wolde vouchesaf to do soo
And that he wolde be oure gouernoᵘur
And of oure tales Iuge and reportoᵘur
And set a soper at a certein pris
And we wil reulid ben at his deuys
In high and lough and þus bi oon assent
We ben accorded vnto the Iugement
And thervpon the wyn was fet anoon
We dronken and to reste went eủer/reychon
Without any lenger taringe
A morwe whan the dai gan to springe
Vp roos oure ost and was oure alde cok
And gadred vs togeder in a flok
And forþ we riden a litel more than pas
Vnto the wateringe of seint Thomas
And þere oure ost gan his hors areste
And seide lordinges herkeneþ if you leste
Ye woot youre forwarde / and I it you recorde

l.hi: If euensong and mornsong accorde

div.l: Lat se now who shal telle þe first tale
As eủer/re mot I drinke wyn or ale
Who so be rebel to my Iugement
Shal paie for al þat bi the waie is spent
Now drawith cut or that we ferþer twynne
Whiche þat hath the shortest shal begynne
SIre knight qd . he mi maist̉er/re and my lorde
Now drawiþ cut for that is myn accorde
Cometh nere qd he my ladi prioresse
And ye sire clerk lat be your shamfastnesse
Ne studieþ not lei honde to euery man
Anoon to drawe eủer/rey wight began
And shortli for to tellen as it was
Were it bi auenture or sort or cas
The soþe is this the cut fel to þe knight
Of which ful bliþe and glad was eủer/rey wight
And tellen he most his tale as it was resoıı̄un
Bi forward and bi composicioıı̄un
As ye han herde what nedeþ wordes moo
And whan this goodman sauh þᵗat it was soo
As he that wis was and obedient
To kepen his forward bi his fre assent
He seide sithen I shal begynne the game
What wolcome be the cut in godis name
Now lat vs ride and herkeneþ what I seie
And wᵗith that worde we riden forþ oure weie
And he began with right amery chere
His tale anoon and seide as ye mai here .
HEre endeþ þe prolog of this book .
(base) Here bigynneth / the knyghtes tale
(base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duc that highte Theseus
(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour
(base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye
(base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
(base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita
(base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree
(base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
(base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) Incipit narracio
(base) ¶ Here bygynneth the knyghtes tale.
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe
(base) Hath alle the bodyes / on an heep ydrawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent
(base) But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
(base) And with that word / withouten moore respit
(base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
(base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
(base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
(base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
(base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
(base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
(base) And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
(base) Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
(base) And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
(base) ¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
(base) So shyneth / in his white Baner large
(base) That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
(base) And by his Baner / born was his penoun
(base) Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
(base) The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
(base) ¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour
(base) And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
(base) Forth he rode with grete power and myght
(base) Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
(base) Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte
(base) ¶ But shortly / for to speken of this thyng
(base) With Creoun / which that was of Thebes kyng
(base) He faught and slow hym manly / as a knyght
(base) In pleyn bataille / and putte the folk to flyght
(base) And by assaut he wan the Citee after
(base) And rente adoun / bothe wal / and sparre / and rafter
(base) And to the ladyes / he restored agayn
(base) The bones / of hir freendes / that were slayn
(base) To doon obsequies / as was tho the gyse
(base) But it weere al to long for to deuyse
(base) The grete clamour / and the waymentynge
(base) That the ladyes made / at the brennynge
(base) Of the bodies / and the grete honour
(base) That Theseus / the noble Conquerour
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Dooth to the ladys / whan they from hym wente
(base) But shortly / for to telle is myn entente
(base) ¶ Whan that this worthy duc this Theseus
(base) Hath Creoun slayn / and wonne Thebes thus
(base) Stille in that feeld / he took al nyght his reste
(base) And dide withal the contree / as hym leste
(base) ¶ To ransake in the taas / of bodies dede
(base) Hem for to strepe / of harneys / and of wede
(base) The pilours / diden bisynesse / and cure
(base) After the bataille / and disconfiture
(base) And so bifel / in the taas they founde
(base) Thurgh girt with many a greuous blody wownde
(base) Two yonge knyghtes / liggynge by and by

And of so ꝑparfit wise and whi Iwrought
Trusteþ right wel þei were not made for nought
Glose who so wil and sei boþe vp and downe
Þat þei were made for pʳgacioıı̄un
Of vryne and oure boþe thinges smale
Were eek to knowe a femal from a male
And for nonoþ̉er cause what seie ye no
Þe experience woot it is not so;
So þat þe clerkes be not wᵗith me wroþe
I seie þis þat þei maked ben for boþe
This is to seien for office and for ese
Of engenderinge þar we not god displese
Whi shulden men elles in hire bookes sette
That man shal yelde to his wif his dette
Now wher wiþ shulde he paie his paiement
If þat he vsed his sely Instrument
Thanne were þei made vpon acreature
To purge vryne and eek for engendrur
Than sholde not eueri wight beholde
Þat haþ suche harneis as I to you of tolde
To gon and vsen hem in engendrure
Than shulde men take of chastite no cure
Crist was amaiden and shapen as aman
And many a saint syn þe worlde began
Yett lyued þei euere in ꝑparfit chastite
Y nyl envie wiþ no virginite
Leet hem ete brede of pured whete seed
And late vs wyues ete barli breed
And ȝitt wiþ barli brede / mark telle can
Oure lord Ihıı̄un refresshed many man
In suche astate as god haþ cleped vs
I wil ꝑperseuere I am not precious
In wifhode wol I vse myn Instrumēmt
As freli as my maker haþ it sent
If I be daungerous god geve me sorow
Mi husbonde shal it haue boþe eve and morow
Whan þat him list come forþ and paie his dette
An husbonde I wil han I wil not lette
Which shal be boþe my dettoᵘur and my þral
And han his tribulacioıı̄un wiþal
Vpon his flesshe while þat I am his wif
I haue the powere during al my lif
Vpon his propre bodi and not he
Right þus þe Apostel tolde vnto me
And bad oure housbondes for to loue vs wel
Al þis sentence me likeþ eueridel
Uppe sterte þe pardon þanne right anoon
Now dame qd he be god and seint Iohn
Ye ben a noble prechoᵘur in þis cas
I was aboute to wedde awif alas
What shulde I bie it on my flessh so der
Yitt hadde I leuere wedde noon to ȝere
Abide qd she my tale is not begonne
Nai þou shalt drinken of anoþ̉er tonne
Or þat I go shal sauoᵘur wors þanne ale
And whanne þat I haue tolde forþ my tale
Of tribulacioıı̄un in mariage
Of whiche I am expert in myn age
This is to seie my selue haþ ben þe whippe
Þan maistow chese wheder þou wolt sippe
Þilke tonne þat I shal abroche
Be war of it or þou to me nie aproche
For I shal telle ensamples moo þan ten
Who so þat wil not be war bi oþ̉er men
Bi him shul oþer men corrected be
This same wordes writeþ Tholome
Rede in his amagest and take it þe
Dame I wolde praie you if youre wil were
Seide þis pardoner as ye began
Telle forþ youre tale spare for noman
And teche vs yonge men of youre practike
Gladli qd she sith it mai you like
But þat I praie to alle þis companye
If þat I speke after my fantasie
As takeþ not agreff of þat I seie
For myn entent is not but for to pleie
Now sires þan shal I telle you my tale
As eủere mot I drinke wyn or ale
I shal seie soþ þo husbondes þat I hadde
As þre of hem were goode men and too were badde
Þe þre were good men and riche and olde
Vnneþe might þei Þe statute holde
In whiche þei were bounden vnto me
Ye woot wel what I mene of this pard
As god me helpe I laughe whan I thinke
How pitousli anight I made hem swynke
But bi my fai I tolde of it no store
Þei hadde me yeue here londe and her tresor
Me neded not do lenger diligence
To wynne hire loue and do hem reủerence
Thei loued me sowel bi god aboue
Þat I ne tolde no deinte of here loue
A wise woman wil besie hir eủere in oon
To gete hire loue þere as she haþ noon
But siþe I hadde hem holi in my honde
And siþe þei had geve me al her londe
What sholde I take kepe hem for to plese
But if it were my profit and myn ese
But sette hem so awerke bi my faie
Þat many a night þe songen welewaie
Þe bacon was not fet for hem I trowe
Þat som men haue in Essex at dıı̄unmowe
I gouerned hem so wel after my lawe
That eche of hem ful bliful was and fawe
To bringe me geie þinges fro þe feire
Knyues and ringes and purs wel feire
For god it woot I chid hem spitousli
Now herkeneþ how I bare me proꝑperli
Ye wise wives þat can vnderstande
Þus shulde ye speke and bere hem wronge on hande

Swere and lie as awoman can

div.l: I seie not þis bi wives þat ben wise
But it be whan þei hem mysavise
A wise wif shal if þat she can hire good
Bere him on honde þat þe kowe is wood
And take wittenesse of hire owne maid
Of hire assent but herkeneþ how I saide
Sir olde keynard is þis þyn arrai
Whi is my neigboᵘurs wif so gai
She is honoured oủere al where she goþe
I sitte at home I haue no þrifti cloþe
What doist þou at my neighboᵘurs hous
Is she so faire art þou so amerous
What rowne ye wiþ oure maide benedicite
Sir olde lechoᵘur lat þi Iapes be
And if I haue agossip or afrende
Wiþoute gilt ye chide as a fende
If þat I walke or pleie vnto his hous
Þou comest hom as dronke as a mous
And prechest on þi benche wᵗith euel preef
Þou seist to me it is a gret myschef
To wedde a poore woman for costage
And if þat she be riche of grete ꝑparage
Þan seist þou it is atormentrie
To suffre hire pride and hire malencolie
And if þat she be faire þou verrai knave
Þou seist þat euery holer wol hir haue
She mai no while in chastite abide Line underlined
Þat is assaide vpon eche side
Þou seist som folke desire vs for richesse
Som for oure shap and som for oure fairnesse
And som for she can oþer singe or daunce
Þus seist þou wernard god geve þe myschaıı̄unce
Som for hir hondes and hire armes smale
Þus goþe al to þe deuel bi þi tale
Þou seist men mai not kepe a castel wal
It mai so longe assailed be oueral
And if þat she be foule þou seist þat she
Coueiteþ eủery man þat she may s
For as as a spaynel she wil on him lepe
Til þat she fynde som man þat wil hire chepe
Ne noon so grey goos goþ þer in þe lake
As seist þow þat wil be withouten make
And seist it is an harde þinge for to welde
A wight þat noman wil his þankes helde
Þus seist þou lorel whan þou gost to bedde
And þat no wise man nedeþ for to wedde
And noman þat entendeþ to þe heuene
Wiþ wilde þunder dynt and fire leuene
mote þi welked necke be to broke
Þou seist þat dropping houses and eek smoke
And chiding wyues maken men to fle
Oute of hire owne houses a benedicite
What eileþ swich an olde man for to chide
Þou seist we wyues wil oures vices hide
Til we be fast and þan we wil hem shewe
Wel mai þis be aprouerbe of a shrewe
Þat saist þat oxen assen hors and houndes
Þei ben assaied at diuers stoundes
Bacyns lauours or þat men hem bie
Sponys stolis and swich husbondrie
And so ben pottys cloþis and oþ̉er arraies
But of women ar maked noon assaies
Tille þei be wedded olde dotard shrewe
And seist how þenne we wil oure vices shewe
Þou seist also þat it displeseþ me
But if þou wilt preise my beute
And but þou poure alwey vpon my face
And clepe me faire dame in euery place
And but þou make afest on þat ilke day
Þat I was born and make me fressh and gay
And but þou do my noreys honoᵘu
And to my chamboᵘur wᵗithynne my bour
And to my fadres folk and his allies
Þus seist þou olde barel ful of lies
And ȝitt of oure aprentis Iankyn
For his crispe heere shinyg so gold fyn
And for he squiers me boþe vp and doıı̄un
Ȝitt hast þou þought and fals suspecioıı̄un
I wil him nought þough þou were dede to morowe
But telle me þis whihidest þou wᵗith sorowe
Þi keies of of þi chest awaie fro me
It is my gode aswel as þin ꝑparde
What wenest þou to make an Ideot of oure dame
Now bi þat lord that called is seint Iame
Þou shalt not boþe þough þat þou wer wood
Be maister of my bodi and of my good
That oon þou shalt for go maugre þin eien
What helpeþ it on me enquere and spien
I trow þough þou woldest lok me in þi chest
Þou shuldest seie wif goo where as þe lest
Take youre disport I wil not leue no tales
I knowe you for agood wif dame Ales
We loue noman þat takeþ kepe or charge
Where þat we goo wil be at oure large
Of alle men blissed mot he be
Þe wise Astrologen Daun Tholome
Þat seiþ þis ꝓprouerbe in his Almagest
Of alle men his wisdam is hiest
Þat reckeþ not who haþ þe worlde in hande
Bi þis ꝓprouerbe þou shalt wel vnderstande
Haue þou I nough what þar þe rekke or care
How merely þat oþer folke fare
For certes olde dotard by youre leue
Ye shulle haue queynt I nough at eu
Be þou never wroþ with myn Instrument
But þou finde þere yn anoþer mannes tent
He is to grete anygarde þat wil warne
Aman to light a candel at his lanterne
He shal haue neủere þe lasse light parde
Haue þou I nough þou þar not pleyne þe
Þou seist also þat if þou make vs gay
Wiþ cloþing or with precious aray
Þat is peril of oure chastite
And yett wiþ wordes þou most enforce me
And seie þese wordes in þe Apostles name
Inabit made wᵗith chastite and shame
Ye women shulde aparaile you qd he
And not intressed heer and gaie perre
As perle ne wiþ gold ne wiþ cloþis riche
Aftir þi text ne aftir þi rubriche
I wil nat werke as mykel as agnatt
Þou seidest als þat I was like a catt
But who so wolde senge a cattes skyn
Þan wolde þe catt wel duellen in his In
And if þe cattes skyn be slike and gai
She nel not duelle in house half a dai
But forþ she wil or any dai be dawed
To shewe hir skyn and goo a caterwawed
Þis is to sai if I be gai sir shrewe
I wil renne out my borel for to shewe
sir olde fool what helpeþ þe tospien
Þough þou preie Argus wiþ his Mᵉ eien
To be my warde corps as he can best
In feiþ he shal not kepe me but if me liste
Yitt couþe I make his berde so mote I þe
Þou seist eeke þat þer be þinges þre
Þe whiche þinges troublen al þis erþ
And þat nowight ne mai endure þe ferþe
O leue sire shrewe Ihıı̄un shorte þi lif
Yett prechest þou and seist an hateful wif
I rekened is for oon þese myschaıı̄unces
Been þer noon noþer man resemblaıı̄unces
þat ye mai liken youre parables to
But if a seli wif be oon of þo
þou likenest womāmnys loue to helle
To bareyne londe þere water mai not duelle
þou likenest it also to wilde fire
þe more it brenneþ þe more it haþ desire
To consume any þine / þat brende wolde be
þou seist þat right as wormes shende a tre
Right so a wyf destroieþ hir husbonde
þis knowen þei þat ben to wyues bonde
Lordinges right þus as ye han vnderstande
Bare I stifli myn olde husbondes an hande
þat þus þei seiden in hire drunkenesse
And eek þat he had suspecion and Ielousnesse
On Iankyn and on my Nese also
O . lord þe peyne I dede hem and þe woo
Ful giltles bi goddes swete pyne
For as an hors I couþe boþe bite ⁊and whyne
I couþe pleyne and I was in þe gilt
Or elles ofte tyme I had ben spilt
Who so first to þe mylle comeþ first grynt
I pleyned first so was oure werre stynt
T hei were ful glade to excusen hem ful blyue
Of þinge of which þei agilt never hire lyue
Of wenches wolde I beren hem on honde
Whan þat forsike þei might vnneþe stonde
Yitt tikeled I his hert for þat he
Wende I had of him so grete chierte
I swore þat al my walking be nighte
For to aspie wenches þat he dighte
Vnder þat coloᵘur had I many amirthe
For al suche witte is yeue vs in oure birþe
Desseite . wepinge . spynnyng god haþ yeue
To woman kindli while þat þei mai lyue
And þus ofoþinge I avaunt me
At þe ende I hadde þe best in eche degre
Bi sleighte or force or bi sum maner þinge
As bi cōmtynuel murmʳ or grucching
Nameli a bedde had þei mischaıı̄unce
There wolde I chide and do hem no plesaıı̄unce
I wolde no lenger in þe bedde abide
If þat I felte his arme over my side
Til he had made his raunson vn to me
Þan wolde I suffre him do his nycete
And þerfore eueri man þis tale I telle
Wyne who so mai al ar for to selle
With empti hande men mai noon hauke lure
For wynnyng wol I al his lust endure
And make me afeyned appetite
And ȝitt in bacon had I neuer delite
Þat maked me þat euer I wolde him chide
For þough þe pope had sette him beside
I wolde not spare him at his owne borde
For bi my trouþe I quytt him worde for worde
As help me verrey god omnipotent
Þough I right now shulde make my testamēmt
I ne owe him a worde þat it nys quytt
I broughte it so aboute by my witte
Þat he muste eve it vp as for þe beste
Or elles had we neủere be in reste
For þough he loked as a lioıı̄u
He sholde yitt faile of his conclusioıı̄un
Than wolde I seie now goode lefe take kepe
How mekeli lokeþ wilkyn oure shepe
Come nere my spouse lat me ba þi cheke
Ye shul be al pacient and meke
And han a swete spiced conscience
Syn ye so preche of Iobis pacience
Suffreþ alweie syn ye so wel can preche
And but ye do / certayne we shul you teche
Þat it is fair to haue awif in pees
Oon of vs mot bowen douteles
And sith aman is moor resonable
Þan woman is sire . ye most be suffreable
What eileþ you to grucche þus and grone
Is it for ye wolde haue my queynt allone
Whi take it al loo . haue it euerydel
Petir I shrewe you but ye loue me wel
For if I wolde selle my bele chose
I couþe walke as fressh as aroose
But I wol kepe it for youre owne toth
Ye be to blame be god I seie you soth
Suche maner wordes had we on honde
Now wil I speke of my ferþe husbonde
My ferþe husbonde was areuelour
This is to seie he had a ꝑparamour
And I was yonge and ful of gerie
Stiborne and stronge and Iolie as a pie
Lord how couþe I daunce to an harpe smale
And singe I wis as any nightingale
Whan I had dronke adrauȝte of swete wyn
Meteling þe foule cherle þe swyn
Þat wiþ a staff bi raft his wif her lif
For she dranke wyn þough I had ben his wi
Ne shulde he nought haue daunted me fro drinke
And after wyn on venus most I þenke
For also siker as colde engendreþ haile
A licorous mouþe most han alicorous taileLine underlined
In women vynolent is no deffence
Þis knowen lechers bi experience
But lord crist whan þat remembreþ me
Vpon my youþe and my Iolite
It tikleþ me aboute my hert roote
Vnto þis dai it doþ my herte bote
That I haue had my world as in my tyme
But age alas þat al wol envenyme
Haþ me raft my beute and my pith
Lat go fare wel þe deuel go þerwith
Þe floure is gon þer is nomore to telle
The bran as I beste can now mote I selle
But yett to be right mery wol I fonde
Now forþe to telle of my ferþe husbonde
I seie I hadde in hert grete dispite
Þat he of any oþ̉er had delite
But he was quyt bi god and bi seint Iose
I made him of þe same wode a crose
Nat of my bodi in no foule manere
But certeinli I made folke suche chere
That in his owne grece I made him frie
For angerie and verrai Ielousie
Be god in erþe I was his purgatorie
For which I hope his soule be in glorie
For god it woot he sat ful oft and songe
Whan þat his sho ful bitterli him wronge
For þ̉er was noon sauf god and he þat wiste
In mony wise whore I him twiste
He died whan I cam fro Ierusale
And lieth I graue vnder þe roode beeme
Al nys his tombe not so corious
As was þe sepulcre of him darius
Whiche þat Appelles wrought subtili
It nys but wast to burie him preciousli
Late him fare wel god geve his soule reste
He is now in his graue and in his cheste
Now of my fifte husbonde wil I telle
God late never his soule come in helle
And yitt was he to me þe most shrewe
That fele I on my ribbes al be rewe
And eủere shal vn to myn ending dai
But in oure bedde he was so fressh and gai
And þerwith also wel couþe he me glose
Whan þat he wolde han my bele chose
That þough he had me bete euery boon
He couþe wynne agayn my loue anoon
I trowe I loued him þe bette for he
Was of his loue daungerous to me
Þe wōmmen han if þat I shal not lie
In this man̉ere a queynt fantasie
Waite what þinge we mai not lightli haue
Thereafter wol we crie aldai and craue
Forbede vs þynge and þat desiren weLine underlined
Pres on vs fast and þan wil we fle
With daunger outen we alle oure cheffare
Grete pres at market makeþ dere wareLine underlined
And to grete chepe is I holde at litel pris
Þis knoweþ euery woman þat is wis
my fifte housbonde god his soule blesse
Which þat I took for loue ⁊and no richesse
He som tyme was a clerc of Oxenford
And had left scole and went at home to bord
Wiþ my gossop dwelling in oure toıı̄unn
God haue hire soule hire name was Alisoıı̄un
She knewe myn hert and al my pryuite
Bettere þanne oure parissh prest so mote I þe
To hire be wreied I my counseil al
For had myn husbond pissed on a wal
Or don aþinge þat shulde haue cost his lif
To hire and to anoþer worthi wif
And to my nece which þat I loue wel
I wolde han tolde his counseil eủerydel
And so I dede fuloften god it woot
Þat made his face often rede ⁊and hoot
For verraie shame and blamed himsilf for he
Had tolde to me so grete apryuete
And so it bifel þat ones in a lente
So ofte time I to my gossip wente
For eủere yitt I loued to be fressh and gai
And for to walke in marche Auerel ⁊and mai
Fro hous to hous to herkene sondri tales
Þat Iankyn clerc / and my gossip dame Ales
And I myself in to þe feldes wente
Myn husbonde was at london al þat lente
I hadde þe better leiser for to pleie
And for to se and eek / for to be seie
Of sondry folk what wist I where my gᵃce
Was shapen for to be or in what place
Therfore made I my visitacoıı̄uns
To vigilies and to processioıı̄uns
To preching eek and to þis pilgrimages
To plaies of miracles and of mariages
And wered vpon my gai scarlet gites
Þis wormes ne þis moþþes ne þis mytes
Vpon my ꝑperile frete hem neủerade
And wost þou whi for þei were vsed wel
Now wol I tellen forþ what happed me
I seie þat in þe feldes walked we
Til trewli we had suche daliaıı̄unce
Þis clerc and I þat of my pʳueaıı̄unce
I spak to him and seide how þat he
If I were wedow sholde wedde me
For certeinly I seie for no bobaıı̄unce
Þat was I neủere yitt wiþout pᵘurueaıı̄unce
Off mariage ne of oþer þinges eke
I holde amous is witt not worþ a like
Þat haþ but oon hool for to stirte too
And if þat faile þanne is al I do
But now sire lat me se what shal seyen
A . ha . be god I haue my tale ageyn
Whan þat my ferþe husbonde was on bere
I wepe algate and made sori chere
As wyues moten for it is vsage
And wiþ my keuerchif couored my visage
But for þat I was pʳueide of amake
I wepe but smale and þat I dar vndertake
To chirche was I born my husbond on morowe
Wiþ neighbours þat for hym made sorowe
And Iankyn oure clerc was oon of þoo
As helpe me god as whan I seie him goo
After þe bere me þoughte he hadde a peire
Of legges and of feete so clene ⁊and feire
Þat al myn hert I gaf vnto his holde
He was I trowe twenty wynter olde
And I was fourti if I shal seie soþe
But ȝitt I hadde alweie a coltes toþe
Gat toþid I was and þat becam me wel
I hadde þe prynte of seint venus see
As helpe me god I was a lusti oon
And faire and riche and yonge and wel be goon
And trewli as myn husbonde tolde me
I had þe best quoniam þat might be
Myn ascendent was taur ⁊and mars þ̉erinne
Allas allas þat eue loue was synne
I folowed aie myne inclinacioıı̄un
Bi vertu of my constellacioıı̄un
Þat made me I couþe nat withdrawe
Mi chambre of venus from agood felawe
Yett haue I mars is marke vpon my face
And also in anoþer previ place
For god so wis be my sauacioıı̄un
I loued neủere bi no discrecioıı̄un
I folwed eủere myn appetite
Al were he longe short blak or white
I took no kepe so þat he liked me
How poor he was and eek of what degre
What sholde I seie but atte þe monþes ende
This Ioli clerc Iankyn þat was so hende
