As to hir verray worldly suffisance
But shortly if this storie I tellen shal
This Markys writen hath in special
A lettre in which he sheweth his entente
And secrely he to Boloigne it sente
To the Erl of Pavyk which that hadde tho
Wedded his suster prayde he specially
To bryngen hom agayn his children two
In honurable estat al openly
With all his hert ful affectuously
But o thyng he hym prayde outrely
With all his herte ful affectuously
That he to no wight thgh men wolde enquere
Sholde nat tellen whos children that they were
But seye the mayden sholde ywedded be
Vn to the Markys of Saluce anon
And as this Erl was prayd so dide he
For at day set he on his wey is gon
And forth he rod / ful fast a noon
Toward Saluce and lordes many oon
Toward Saluce / this Mayde for to gyde
In riche array this mayden for to gyde
Hir yonge brother ridyng hir bisyde
Arrayed was toward hir mariage
This fresshe mayde ful of gemmes clere
Hir brother which that seuen yeer was of age
Arrayed eek ful fressh in his manere
And thus in gret noblesse and with glad cheere
Toward Saluces shapyng hir iourney
Fro day to day they ryden in hir wey

l.hi: Explicit quarta pars

div.l: Incipit pars quinta
Among al this after his wikke vsage
Incipit pars qᵃnta et Vltima
This Markys yet his wif to tempte moore
To the outreste preue of hir corage
Fully to han experience and loore
If that she were as stedefast as bifore
He on a day in open audience
Ful boystously hath seyd hir this sentence
Certes Grisilde I hadde ynogh plesance
To han yow to my wyf for your goodnesse
As for youre trouthe and for your obeysance
Noght for your lynage ne for your richesse
But now knowe I in verray sothfastnesse
That in gret lordshipe if I wel auyse
Ther is gret seruitute in sondry wyse
I may nat do as euery Plowman may
My peple me constreyneth for to take
Another wyf and cryen day by day
And eek the pope rancour for to slake
Consenteth it that dar I vndertake
And trewely thus muche I wol yow seye
My newe wif is comynge by the weye
Be strong of herte and voyde anon hir place
And thilke dower that ye broghten me
Tak it agayn I graunte it of my grace
Retourneth to youre fadres hous quod he
No man may alwey han prosperitee
With euene herte I rede yow tendure
The strook of Fortune or of auenture
And she agayn answerde in pacience
My lord quod she I woot and wiste alway
How that bitwixen youre magnificence
And my pouerte no wight kan ne may
Maken comparisoun it is no nay
I ne heeld me neuere digne in no manere
To be your wyf no ; ne youre chambrere
And in this hous ther ye me lady made
The heighe god take I for my witnesse
And also wisly he my soule glade
I neuere heeld me lady ne maistresse
But humble seruant to youre worthynesse
And euere shal whil that my lyf may dure
Abouen euery worldly creature
That ye so longe of youre benygnytee
Han holden me in honour and nobleye
Where as I was noght worthy for to be
That thonke I god and yow to whom I preye
Foryelde it yow ther is namoore to seye
Vn to my fader gladly wol I wende
And with hym dwelle vn to my lyues ende
Ther I was fostred of a child ful smal
Til I be deed my lyf ther wol I lede
A wydewe clene in body herte and al
For sith I yaf to yow my maydenhede
And am youre trewe wyf it is no drede
God shilde swich a lordes wyf to take
Another man to housbond or to make
And of youre newe wyf god of his grace
So graunte yow wele and prosperitee
For I wol gladly yelden hir my place
In which that I was blisful wont to be
For sith it liketh yow my lord quod she
That whilom weren al myn hertes reste
That I shal goon I wol goon whan yow leste
But ther as ye me profre swich dowaire
As I first broghte it is wel in my mynde
It were my wrecched clothes no thyng faire
The whiche to me were hard now for to fynde
O goode god how gentil and how kynde
Ye semed by your speche and your visage
The day that maked was oure mariage
But sooth is seyd algate I fynde it trewe
For in effect it proued is on me
Loue is noght old as whan that it is newe
But certes lord for noon aduersitee
To dyen in this cas it shal nat be
That euere in word or werk I shal repente
That I yow yaf myn herte in hool entente
My lord ye woot that in my fadres place
Ye dide me strepe out of my poure wede
And richely me cladden of youre grace
To yow broghte I noght ellis out of drede
But feith and nakednesse and maydenhede
And here agayn my clothyng I restore
And eek my weddyng ryng for euere moore
The remenant of your Iewels redy be
Inwith your chambre dar I saufly sayn
Naked out of my fadres hous quod she
I cam and naked moot I turne agayn
Al youre plesance wol I folwen fayn
But yet I hope it be nat youre entente
That I smoklees out of your palays wente
Ye koude nat doon so dishoneste a thyng
That thilke wombe in which youre children leye
Sholde biforn the peple in my walkyng
Be seyn al bare wher fore I yow preye
Lat me nat lyk a worm go by the weye
Remembre yow myn owene lord so deere
I was youre wyf thogh I vnworthy weere
Wher fore in gerdou of my maydenhede
Which that I broghte and noght agayn I bere
As voucheth sauf to yeue me to my mede
But swich a smok as I was wont to were
That I ther with may wrye the wombe of here
That was youre wyf and here I take my leeue
Of yow myn owene lord lest I yow greeue
The smok quod he that thow hast on thy bak
Lat it be stille and bere it forth with thee
But wel vnnethes thilke word he spak
But wente his wey for routhe and for pitee
Biforn the folk hir seluen strepeth shee
And in hir smok with heued and feet al bare
Toward hir fader hous forth is she fare
The folk hir folwen wepynge in hir weye
And Fortune ay they cursen as they goon
But she fro wepyng kepte hir eyen dreye
Ne in this tyme word ne spak she noon
Hir fader that this tidynge herde anon
Curseth the day and tyme that nature
Shoop hym to been a lyues creature
For out of doute this olde poure man
Was euere in suspect of hir mariage
For euere he demed sith that it bigan
That whan the lord fulfild hadde his corage
Hym wolde thynke it were a disperage
To wedde oon of so pore alynage
To his estat so lowe for talighte
And voyden hir as soone as euere he myghte
Agayns his doghter hastiliche goth he
For he by noyse of folk knew hir comynge
And with hir olde cote as it myghte be
He couered hire ful sorwefully wepynge
But on hir body myghte he it nat brynge
For rude was the clooth and she moore of age
By dayes fele than at hir mariage
Thus with hir fader for a certein space
Dwelleth this flour of wifly pacience
That neyther by hir wordes ne hir face
Biforn the folk ne eek in hir absence
Ne shewed she that hir was doon offence
Ne of hir heighe estat no remembrance
Ne hadde she as by hir contenance
No wonder is for in hir grete estat
Hir goost was euere in pleyn humylitee
No tendre mouth noon herte delicat
No pompe no semblant of realtee
But ful of pacient benygnytee
Discreet and pridelees ay honurable
And to hir housbonde euere meke and stable
Men speke of Iob and moost for his hunblenesse
As clerkes whan hem lest konne wel endite
Namely of men but as in soothfastnesse
Thogh clerkes preyse wommen but alite
Ther kan no man in humblesse hym acquite
As wommen kan ne kan be half so trewe
As wommen been but it be falle of newe
¶ . Quinta pars .
Incipit pars Sexta
Fro Boloigne is this Erl of Pavyk come
Of which the fame vp sprong to moore and lesse
And to the peples erys alle and some
Was kouth eek that a newe Markisesse
He with hym broghte in swich pomp and richesse
That neuere was ther seyn with mannes eye
So noble array in al westlumbardye
The Markys which that shoop and knew al this
Er that this Erl was come sente his message
For thilke sely poure Grisildis
And she with humble herte and glad visage
Nat with no swollen thoght in hir corage
Cam at his heste and on hir knees hir sette
And reuerently and wysly she hym grette
Grisilde quod he my wyl is outrely
This mayden that shal wedded been to me
Receyued be tomorwe as really
As it possible is in myn hous to be
And eek that euery wight in his degree
Haue his estat in sittyng and seruyse
And heigh plesance as I kan best deuyse
I haue no wommen suffisant certayn
The chambres for taraye in ordynance
After my lust and ther fore wolde I fayn
That thyn were al swich manere gouernance
Thow knowest eek of old al my plesance
Though thyn array be badde and yuel biseye
Do thow thy deuoir at the leeste weye
Nat oonly lord that I am glad quod she
To doon youre lust but I desire also
Yow for to serue and plese in my degree
With outen feyntyng and shal euere mo
Ne neuere for no wele ne no wo
Ne shal the goost with Inne myn herte stente
To loue yow best with al my trewe entente
And with that word she gan the hous to dighte
And tables for to sette and beddes make
And peyned hir to doon al that she myghte
Preyynge the chambreres for goddes sake
To hasten hem and faste swepe and shake
And she the mooste seruysable of alle
Hath euery chambre arrayed and his halle
Abouten vndren gan this Erl alighte
That with hym broghte thise noble children tweye
For which the peple ran to seen the sighte
Of hire array so richely biseye
And thanne at erst amonges hem they seye
That Walter was no fool thogh that hym leste
To chaunge his wyf for it was for his beste
For she is fairer as they demen alle
Than is Grisilde and moore tendre of age
And fairer fruyt bitwene hem sholde falle
And moore plesant for hir heigh lynage
Hir brother eek so fair was of visage
That hem to seen the peple hath caught plesance
Commendynge now the Markys gouernance
O stormy peple vnsad and euere vntrewe
Ay vndiscreet and chaungynge as a vane
Delitynge euere in rumbel that is newe
Here may ye se the peple how newe
For lyk the moone ay wexe ye and wane
Ay ful of clappyng deere ynow a Iane
And changeable be right as the mane
Youre doom is fals youre constance yuele preueth
A ful greet fool is he that on yow leueth
Thus seyden sadde folk in that Citee
Whan that the peple gazed vp and doun
For they were glad right for the noueltee
To han a newe lady of hir town
Namoore of this make I now mencioun
But to Grisilde agayn wol I me dresse
And telle hir constance and hir bisynesse
Ful bisy was Grisilde in euery thyng
That to the feste was apertinent
Right noght was she abayst of hir clothyng
Thogh it were rude and somdel eek to rent
But with glad cheere to the yate is she went
With oother folk to greete the Markysesse
And after that dooth forth hir bisynesse
With so glad cheere his gestes she receyueth
And so konnyngly euerich in his degree
That no defaute no man aparceyueth
But ay they wondren what she myghte be
That in so poure array was for to se
And koude swich honour and reuerence
And worthily they preysen hir prudence
In al this mene while she ne stente
This mayde and eek hir brother to commende
With al hir herte in ful benygne entente
So wel that no man koude hir prys amende
But at the laste whan that thise lordes wende
To sitten doun to mete he gan to calle
Grisilde as she was bisy in his halle
Grisilde quod he as it were in his pley
How liketh thee my wyf and hir beautee
Right wel quod she my lord for in good fey
A fairer saw I neuere noon than she
I prey to god yeue hire prosperritee
And so hope I that he wol to yow sende
Plesance ynogh vn to youre lyues ende
O thyng biseke I yow and warne also
That ye ne prike with no tormentynge
For she is fostred in hir norissynge
Moore tendrely and to my supposynge
She koude nat aduersitee endure
As koude a poure fostred creature
And whan this Walter saw hir pacience
Hir glad cheere and no malice at al
And he so ofte had doon to hir offence
And she ay sad and constant as a wal
Continuynge euere hir Innocence ouer al vbique
With pacience Grisild he quiteth
This sturdy Markys gan his herte dresse
To rewen vp on hir wifly stedfastnesse
This is ynogh Grisilde myn quod he
Be now namoore agast ne yuele apayed
I haue thy feith and thy benygnytee
Mankynde which that he wroght
As wel as euere womman was assayed
In greet estat and poureliche arrayed
Now knowe I deere wyf thy stedfastnesse
And hire in armes took and gan hir kesse
And she for wonder took of it no keep
She herde nat what thyng he to hir seyde
She ferde as she hadde stirt out of a sleep
Sche ferd as sche had stert oute of hir slepe
Til she out of hir mazednesse abreyde
Grisilde quod he by god that for vs deyde
Thow art my wyf noon oother I haue
Ne neuere hadde as god my soule saue
This is thy doghter which thow hast supposed
To be my wyf that oother feithfully
Shal be myn heir as I haue ay supposed
Thow bare hym in thy body trewely
At Boloigne haue I kept hem priuely
Tak hem agayn for now maistow nat seye
That thow hast lorn noon of thy children tweye
And folk that oother weys han seyd of me
I warne hem wel that I haue doon this dede
For no malice ne for no crueltee
But for tassaye in thee thy wommanhede
And nat to sleen my children god forbede
But for to kepe hem pryuely and stille
Til I thy purpos knewe and al thy wille
Whan she this herde aswowne doun she falleth
For pitous ioye and after hir swownynge
She bothe hir yonge children vn to hir calleth
And in hir armes pitously wepynge
Embraceth hem and tendrely kissynge
Ful lyk a moder with hir salte terys
She batheth bothe hir visage and hir herys
O which a pitous thyng it was to se
O such a pitous thing it was to see
Hir swownyng and hir humble voys to heere
Grant mercy lord god thanke it yow quod she
That ye han saued me my children deere
Now rekke I neuere to been ded right heere
Sith I stonde in your loue and in youre grace
No fors of deeth ne whan my spirit pace
O tendre o deere o yonge children myne
Youre woful moder wende stedefastly
That cruel houndes or som foul vermyne
Hadde eten yow but god of his mercy
And youre benygne fader tendrely
Hath doon yow kept and in that same stounde
Al sodeynly she swapte adoun to grounde
And in hir swogh so sadly holdeth she
Hir children two whan she gan hem tembrace
That with greet sleghte and greet difficultee
The children from hir arm they gonne arace
O many a teer o many a pitous face
Doun ran of hem that stoden hir bisyde
Vnnethe aboute hir myghte they abyde
Walter hir gladeth and hir sorwe slaketh
She riseth vp abaysed from hir traunce
And euery wight hir ioye and feste maketh
Til she hath caught agayn hir contenaunce
Walter hir dooth so feithfully plesaunce
That it was deyntee for to seen the cheere
Bitwix hem two now they ben met yfeere
Thise ladies whan that they hir tyme say
Han taken hir and in to chambre goon
And strepen hir out of hir rude aray
And in a clooth of gold that brighte shoon
With a coroune of many a riche stoon
Vp on hir hed they in to halle hir broghte
And ther she was honured as hir oghte
Thus hath this pitous day a blisful ende
For euery man and womman dooth his myght
This day in murthe and reuel to dispende
Til on the welkne shoon the sterres lyght
For moore solempne in euery mannes syght
This feste was and gretter of costage
Than was the reuel of hir mariage
Ful many a yeer in heigh prosperitee
Lyuen thise two in concord and in reste
And richely his doghter maried he
Vn to a lord oon of the worthyeste
Of al Ytaille and thanne in pees and reste
His wyues fader and his court he kepeth
Til that the soule out of his body crepeth
His sone succedeth in his heritage
In reste and pees after his fader day
And fortunat was eek his mariage
Al putte he nat his wyf in gret assay
This world is nat so strong it is no nay
As it hath been in olde tymes yore
And herkneth what this Auctour seith therfore
This storie is seyd nat for that wyues sholde
Folwen Grisilde as in humylitee
For it were inpor table thogh they wolde
But for that euery wight in his degree
Sholde be constant in aduersitee
As was Grisilde therfore Petrak writeth
This storie which he with heigh stile enditeth
For sith a womman was so pacient
Vn to a mortal man wel moore vs oghte
Receyuen al in gree that god vs sent
For gret skile is he preue that he wroghte
But he ne tempteth no man that he boghte
As seith Seint Iame if ye his pistel rede
He preueth folk al day it is no drede
And suffreth vs as for oure excercise
With sharpe scourges of aduersitee
Ful ofte to be bete in sondry wise
Nat for to knowe oure wyl for certes he
Er we were born knew al oure freletee
And for oure beste is al his gouernance
Lat vs thanne lyue in vertuous suffrance
But o word lordynges herkneth er I go
It were ful hard to fynde now a dayes
In al a town Grisildis thre or two
For if that they were put to swiche assayes
The gold of hem hath now so badde alayes
With bras that thogh the coigne be fair at eye
It wolde rather breste atwo than plye
For which heere for the wyues loue of Bathe
Whos lyf and al hir secte god mayntene
In heigh maistrie or ellis were it scathe
I wol with lusty herte fressh and grene
Seye yow a song to glade yow I wene
And lat vs stynte of ernestful matere
Herkneth my song that seith in this manere

l.hi: Here is ended the tale of the clerk of Oxenford

div.l: Lenuxx xx Chaucer ~~~~ ~~~~
GRisild is dede and eek hire pacience
And boþe attones buried in Italie
For wiche I crie in open audience
ed man be hardi to assaile
His wifes pacience in trust to fynde
Grisildes for in certeyne he shal faile
O noble wifes ful of high prudence
Lat noon humilite youre tonge naile
Ne lat no clerke haue cause ne diligence
To write of you a storie of such mervaile
As of Grisildes pacient and kynde
Lest chycheuache you swolow in hir entraile
Folwith ekko þat holdeþ no silence
But eue aunswereþ at þe countirtaile
Beþ not be daffed for youre Innocence
But sharpeli take on you þe gouernaile
Enprentiþ wel þis lesson in youre mynde
For comon ꝓprofit sith it mai availe
E drede hem nought doþ hem no reủer/reence
For þough þin husbond arrmed be in maile
Þe arowes of þi crabbed eloquence
Shal ꝑper/parse his brest and eek his aduentaile
In Ialousie I reede eek þau him bynde
And þat þou make him couche as doþ a quaile
If þou be faire þer folk ben in present
Shew þou þi visage and þin apparaile
If þou be foule be fre of þine despence
To gete þe frendes aie do þi trauaile
Be aie of chere as light as lef on lynde
And lete him care and wepe and wring and waile
E arche wifes stondeþ at youre diffence
Siþe ye ben stronge as is a grete Camaile
Ne suffriþ not þat man do you offence
And slendre wifes feble as in bataile
Beþ egre as a tigre yonde in ynde
Ay clappith as a mylle I you counsaile
Here endeþ þe clerkes tale of oxenford .

Here endeþ þe clerkes tale of oxenford
Here begynneþ þe prolog of þe man of lawe
Oure host saugh wel þat þe bright sonne
The ark of his artificial dai haþ ronne
Þe ferthe part and half an houre and more
And þough he were not depe I stert in lore
He wist it was the eightene dai ¶Þ
Of April whiche is messager to Mai
And saugh wel þat þe shadwe of eủer/rey tre
Was as in lengþe the same quantite
Þat was þe bodi erect þat caused it
And therfore bi þe shadwe he toke his witte
Þat Phebus whiche þat shon so faire and bright
Degres was fyue and fourti clomben in hight
And for þat dai as in latitude
It is ten at clok he gan conclude
And sodenli he plught his hors a boute
Lordynges qd he I warne you al þis route
The ferþe part of þis dai is gon
Now for þe loue of god and of seint Iohn
Lesith no time as ferforþ as ye mai
Lordinges þe tyme wasteþ night and dai
And stelis fro vs / what priueli sleping
And what þurgh negligence in oure waking
As doþ þe streem þat neuer tʳneþ a yen
Descending fro þe mounteyne into þe pleyn
Wel can Senec and many a philosophre
Bewaile time more þan gold in cofre
For losse of catel mai recouered be
But losse of time shendeþ vs qd he
Hit wolnot come ayen wiþout drede
Nomore þan wil malkyns maidenhede
Whan she haþ lost it in hir wantonesse
Let vs not moulen þus in Idelnesse
Sire man of lawe so haue ye blisse
Tel vs a tale anoon as forward is
Ye ben submitt þorgh yoᵘur fre assent
To stonden in þis caas at my Iugement
Acquyteth you now of youre behest
Þanne haue ye don youre deuer at leste
Host de par dieux qd he I assent
To breke forward is nat myn entent
Behest is dette and I wol holde fayn
Al my behest I can no better sayn
For suche lawe as aman yueþ anoþ̉er/re wight
He shulde himsilf vsen it be right
Thus wol oure text but naþeles certeyne
I cannot now no thrifti tale seyne
That Chaucer þough he can bot lewitly
On metris and in rymyng craftili
He saide hem in suche englissh as he can
Of olde time as knoweþ mony man
And if he haue not seide hem leue broþ̉er/re
In on book he haþ said hem in anoþ̉er/re
For he hath told of louers vp and doun
Moo þan Ouyde made of mencioıı̄un
In his epistles þat ben olde
What shulde I tellen hem syn þai ben tolde
In youþe he made of Ce and alkyone
And sithen haþ he spoken of eủer/reychone
Þise noble wyues and þise louers eke
Who so þat wol hir large volum seke
Clepid þe seyntis legende of Cupide
There mai he se þe large volumes wide
Of lucres and of babilon tisbe
The swerd of Dido for þe fals Ene
Þe tre of philles for hir demephon
The pleynt of Dyaniyre and of Ermyon
Of Adrian and of Isiphalee
The bareyn Ile stonding in þe see
The dreynt leander for his erro
The teris of Eleyn and eek þe woo
Off brixside and of þe ladomea
Þe cruelte of þe quene medea
Þe litel children honging bi þe hals ¶Þ
For þi Iason þat was of loue fals
Orphinistra penolape alceste
Youre wifhode he comendith beste
But certeynli noword ne writeþ he
Of þilke wicked ensample of Canace
Þat loued hir owne brothir synfulli
On whiche cursid stories I sei fi
Or elles of thiro Appoloneus
How þat he cursed king Antiochus
Biraft his doughter of hir maidenhede
Þat is so orrible atale for to rede
Whan he hir threw vpon the pavyment
And þerfore he of felle avisement
Nolde neủer/re write in non of his sermouns
Of suche vnkinde abhominacioıı̄uns
Ne I wil noon reherce if þat I mai
But of my tale how shal I do to dai
Me were loth to be likened doutles

(base) ¶ Thanne yif me leyser fader myn quod she
(base) My deeth for to compleyne a litel space
(base) For pardee Iepte yaf his doghter grace
(base) For to compleyne er he hir slowe allas
(base) And god it woot no thyng was hir trespas
(base) But for she ran hir fader for to se
(base) To wel come hym with greet solempnytee
(base) And with that word she fil aswowne anon
(base) And after whan hir swownyng is agon
(base) She riseth vp and to hir fader sayde
(base) Blessed be god that I shal dye a mayde
(base) Yif me my deeth er that I haue a shame
(base) Dooth with youre child youre wyl a goddes name
(base) And with that word she preyed hym ful ofte
(base) That with his swerd he wolde smyte softe
(base) And with that word aswowne doun she fil
(base) ¶ Hir fader with ful sorweful herte and wil
(base) Hir heed of smoot and by the top it hente
(base) And to the Iuge he gan it to presente
(base) As he sat yet in doom in Consistorie
(base) ¶ And whan the Iuge it saw as seith the storie
(base) He bad to take hym and anhange hym faste
(base) But right anon a thousand peple In thraste
(base) To saue the knyght for routhe and for pitee
(base) For knowen was the false Iniquitee
(base) ¶ The peple anon hadde suspect in this thyng

div.l: (base) By manere of the cherles chalangyng
(base) That it was by the assent of Apius
(base) They wisten wel that he was lecherus
(base) For which vnto this Apius they gon
(base) And caste hym in a prison right anon
(base) Ther as he slow hymself and Claudius
(base) That seruant was vnto this Apius
(base) Was demed for to hange vpon a tree
(base) But that Virginius of his pitee
(base) So preyde for hym that he was exiled
(base) And ellis certes he hadde been bigyled
(base) The remenant were anhanged moore and lesse
(base) That were consentant of this cursednesse
(base) ¶ Heere may men seen how synne hath his merite
(base) Beth war for no man woot whom god wol smyte
(base) In no degree ne in which manere wise
(base) The worm of conscience may agrise
(base) Of wikked lyf thogh it so pryuee be
(base) That no man woot ther of but god and he
(base) For be he lewed man or ellis lered
(base) He noot how soone that he shal been afered
(base) Therfore I rede yow this conseil take
(base) Forsaketh synne er synne yow forsake
(base) ¶ Here endeth the Phisiciens tale

div.l: Radix omniıı̄un malorum est cupiditas .
First I ꝓpronıı̄unce whens þat I come
And þenne my bulles shewe all and some
Oure liege lordes seal on my patent
Þat shew I first my bodi to warent
Þat noman be so bolde prest ne clerc
Me to disturbe of cristes holi werk
And aftir þat telle I forþ my tales
Bulles of popes and of Cardynales
Of patriarkes and bisshops I shewe
And in latyn I speke wordes fewe
To sauer wᵗith my predicacioıı̄un
And for to stire men to deuocioıı̄un
Þen shewe I forþ my long cristal stones
I crōmmed ful of cloutes and of bones
Reliques þei ben as wene þei vchone
Þan haue I in laton a shulder bone
Whiche þat was an holi Iewes shepe
Gode men sai I take at my wordes kepe
If . þat þis bon be wasshen in a welle
If cowe or calf shepe or oxe swelle
Þat any worme haþ eten or stong
Aboute þe herte or elles þe long
And it is hool anoon and forþermore
Of pokkes and of scabbes and eủer/rey sore
Shal eủer/rey shepe be hool þat of þis welle
Drinkeþ a draught tak hede what I telle
If þat þe goodman þat þe bestꝭes owith
Wol eủer/rey wook or þat þe cok him crowith
Fasting drink of þis wel a draught
As þilke holi Iewe oure eldres taught
His bestis and his stoor shal multiplie
And sires also it helith Ialousie
And þough aman be falle in a Ialous rage
Lete maken wiþ þis watir his potage .
And neue shal he his wif mistruste
Þough he þe soþ of hir defaute wiste
Al had she taken prestis too . or þre
Here is a miteyn eke þat ye mai se
He þat his hande wol put in þis myteyne
He shal haue multeplyeng of his greyne
Whan he haþ sowen be it whete or otes
So þat he bringe me good pens or grotes
And men and womēm oo . þing I warne yow
If any wight be in þis chirche now
Þat haþ don synne horrible þat he
Dar not for shame of it shryuen be
Or any woman be she yong or olde
Þat haþ made hire husbonde Cokewolde
Suche folk shul haue no power ne no gᵃce
To offre to my reliques in þis place
And who so findeþ him out of suche blame
Þei wol come vp and offre in goddes name
And I assoile him bi þe auctorite
Suche as my bulle was grᵃunted to me
Bi þis gaude haue I wonne eủer/rey ȝere
An hundred marc / sithyns I was ꝑper/pardone
I stande lik a clerc / in my pulpitte
And shewe lewde peples synne
I preche so as I haue lered before
And telle an hundred Iapes more
Þen peyne I me to strecche forþ þe necke
And est . and west vpon þe peple I becke
As doþ a dowue sittyng vpon a berne
Mi hondes and my tonge goon ful yerne
That it is ioie to se my besynesse
Of Auarice and suche cursidnesse
Is al my preching for to make hem fre
To yeue hire pans and nameli vn to me
For myne entent is not but for to wynne ¶þ
And noþing for correccioıı̄un of synne
I rekke neue whan þat þei be buried
Þough þat hire soules goon a blakburied
For certes mony a pdicacioıı̄un
Comeþ oft tyme of euel intencioıı̄un
Som for plesaunce of folk and for flatrie
To ben auaıı̄unced bi Ipocⁱsie
And som for veyn glorie and for hate
For when I darnot oþer waies debate
Þen wil I styng hem wᵗith my tong smert
In preching so þat he shal not a stert
To ben diffamed falsli so þat he
Haþ trespaced to my brethern or to me
For þough I telle not his ꝓpropre name
Men shal wel knowe þat it is þe same
Bi som signe and oþer circumstaıı̄unces
Thus smyte I folk þat doþ vs displesaıı̄unces
Thus spete I out my venym vnder hew
Of holynesse / to semen holi and trew
But shortli myn entent I wil deuyse
I preche of noþing but of couetise
Þerfore my teme is ȝitt and eue was
Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
Þus can I preche ayen þe same vice
Whiche þat I vse and þat is auarice
But þough my silf be giltif in þat synne
I can I make oþer folk to wynne
From Auarice and sore hem repent
But þat nys not my principal entent
I preche not but for couetise
Of þis matier it aught I now suffise
Þen telle I hem ensamples many oon
Of olde stories longe time a goon
For lewed peple louen tales olde
Suche þinges con þei report and holde
What trowe ye þat whiles I mai preche
And wynne gold and siluer for to teche
Þat I wil lyue in pouert wilfulli
Nai nai I thought it neue trewli
For I wil preche and begge in sondri londes
I wil not do no laboᵘur wᵗith my hondes
Ne make baskettis and lyue þerbi
Be cause I wil not lyuen Idulli
I wil noon of þe Aposteles coıı̄unterfete
I wil haue money malt chese and whete
Al were it yeuen of þe porest page
Oþer of þe porest widow in a village
Al shulde hir children sterue or famyne
And I wil drinke þe licorest of þe wyne
And haue a Ioli wenche in eủer/rey toune
But herkeneth lordes in conclusioıı̄un
Youre liking is þat I shal telle a tale
Now I haue dronke a draught of corny ale
Be god I hope I shal telle you a þing
Þat shal be reson at youre liking
For þough my self be a ful vicious man
A moral tale yitt I you telle can
Which I am / / wonte to preche for to wynne
Now holdeþ yoᵘur pees my tale I wol begynne
In flaundres whilom was a companye
Of yonge folk þat haunted folie
As hasard riot stewes and tauernes
Harpes ribibes lutes and giternes
Þei daıı̄unce and plaie at þe dic night and dai
And ete also over þat hire might mai
Þurgh whiche þei do þe deuel sacrifice
Wiþinne þe deuels temple in sondri wise
Bi suꝑper/parfluite abhominable
Here othes ben so grete and dampnable
Þat it is grisli for to hire hem swere
Oure blissed lordes bodi þei to tere
Hem þought Iewes rent him not I now ¶þꝑper/par
And ilke of hem at oþers synne low
And right anoon þen come In tomblisters
Fetis and smal and yong fruterers
Syngers wᵗith harpes . baudes and wafrers
Suche ben verrai þe deuels officers
To kyndle and blow þe fuyre of lecherie
Þat is annexid to glotonye
Þe holi writte take I to witnesse
Þat lecherie is in wyne and dronkenesse
Loo how dronken loth vnkindeli
Lai bi his doughtres too vnwittyngli
So dronke he was he nyst what he wroght
Nolite inebriari vino in quo est luxuria . ~~~ .
Herodes who so haþ þe stories sought
Whan he of wyne replete was at his feste
Right at his owne table ȝaf his heste
To slen þe Baptist Iohn ful gilteles
SEnec saiþ a good worde douteles
He saiþ he can no difference finde
Betwixt aman þat is out of his mynde
And aman þat is dronkelew
But þat woodnesse is fallen in a shrew
ꝐPer/Parseuereþ lenger þan doþ dronkenesse
O . glotonie ful of cursidnesse
O . cause first of oure confusioıı̄un
Original of oure dampnacioıı̄un
Til crist had bought vs wᵗith his blood agayn
Loo how dere shortli for to sayn
A bought was þe cursid vilanye
Corrupt was al þis world þurgh glotonye
Adam oure fader and his wif alsoo
Fro paradis to laboᵘur / and to woo
Were dryuen for þat wise it is no drede
For whiles þat Adam fasted as I rede

Iero9 . coᵃn Iommanıı̄un . Qᵃm diu ieiunauit adam in para .
diso fuit . Comedit et eiectus est statim . ~~~~ . ~~~~
He was in paradis and whan þat he
Ete of þe fruyt / defended on þe tre
A noon he was out cast to woo and peyne
O . glotonye on þe wel ought vs pleyne
O . wist aman how many maladies
Folowiþ of excesse and of glotonies
He wolde ben þe more mesurable
Of his diete sitting at his table
Allas þe short þrote þe tendre mouþe
Makeþ þat . Est . west . north / and south .
In erþe in eier in water men to synke
To gete a gloton deynte mete and drinke
Of þis matiere . o paule wel can þou trete
Mete vn to wombe / and wombe eke vnto mete
Shal god destroie both as paule seiþ
Alas a foule þing it is bi my faith
To sai þis worde and fouler is þe dede
When men so drinkeþ of þe white and rede
Þat of his þrote he makeþ his preue
Þurgh þilke cursid suꝑper/parfluite
T he Apostel weping saiþ ful pitousli
Ther walken mony of wiche told haue I
I sai it now weping wᵗith pitous vois
Ther ben enemyes of cristes crois
Of whiche þe ende is deþ wombe is her god
O . wombe o . bali / o . stynking cod /
Fulfilled of donge and of corrupcioıı̄un
Atte eiþer ende of þe foule is þe ceson
How grete cost and laboᵘur is to finde
Þise cokes how þei stampe streyne and grinde
And tʳnen substaunce in to accident
To fulfille al þi licorous talent
Out of þe harde bones knokke þei
Þe mari for þei cast not aweie
Þat mai goo þurgh þe golet saf and soote
Of spicerie of leue bark and roote ¶þꝑper/par
Shal ben his sauce made be delite
To maken him ȝitt a newe appetite
But certeyn he þat haunteþ suche delices
Is dede whiles he lyueþ in þo vices
A licherie þing is wyne and dronkenesse
It is ful of stryuyng and of wrecchidnesse
O . dronken man disfigured in þi face
Foule is þi breth / foule art þou to enbrace
And þurgh þi dronken nose sowneþ þe sone
As þogh þou seidest ai . sampson sampson
And yitt god woot sampson dronke neue no wyne
Þou fallest as it were a dronken swyne
Þi tonge is lost and al þi honest cure
For dronkennesse is verrai sepulture
Of mannys witte / and his discrecoıı̄un
In whom þat drinke haþ dominacoıı̄un
He can no counseil kepe it is no drede
Now kepe you from þe white and from þe rede
Nameli from þe white wyn of lepe
Þat is to selle in fisshe strete and in chepe
Þis wyn of spayn crepiþ subtilly
In oþer wynes growyng fast bi
Of whiche riseþ suche fumosite
Þat whan aman haþ dronke adraught or þre
And weneþ þat he be at home in chepe
Þan is he in spayne right at þe toıı̄un of lepe
Not at rochel ne at bordeux tou
And þen wol þei sai Sampson sampsou
But herkenyth / lordyng oo . worde I you pᵃie
Þat alle þe souerayne actes dar I sai
Of victories in olde testament
Þat þurgh verrai god þat is omnipotent
Were don in abstinence and in pᵃiere
Lokeþ þe bible and þere ye mai it lere
Lokiþ Attila þe grete conqueroᵘur
Died in his slepe wiþ shame and dishonoᵘur
Bleding at his nose in dronkenesse
A Capitayne shulde lyue in sobirnesse
And oue al þise avise you right welle
What was cōmmaunded vnto lamuelle
Not samuel but lamuel sai I
Redith þe bible and findeþ it expresseli
Of wyn ȝeuyng of hem þat aren Iustice
Nomore of þis for it mai suffice
Now syn I haue spoken of glotonie
Now wol I defende you hasardie
Poli Iiᵒ iᵒ . Mendaciorum et ꝑper/pariuriorum mat̉er/re est alea .
Hasard is verrai moder of lesinges
And of disceit cursid for sweringes
Blaspheme of crist manslauht̉er/re and wast also
Of bataile and of time and forthermo
It is repreef and contrarie to honoᵘur
For to beholden a comou hasardoᵘur
And eue þe hier he is of estate
The more he is holden desolate
If þat a prynce vse hasardie
In alle gouernaıı̄unce and policie
He is as bi comou opiniou
Holde þe lasse in reputaciou
Stilbon þat was hold a wise enbassatoᵘur
Was sende in to corinth wᵗith ful gret honoᵘur
Fro Calydoyne to make hem alliaıı̄unce
And whan he cam happid this chaıı̄unce
Þat alle þe grettest þat were of þat londe
Pleieng atte hasard he hem fonde
For whiche assone as þat might be
He stale him home ayen to his cuntre
And saide þer I wold not lese my name
I wolde not take on me so grete diffame
For to Allie you to none hasardoures
Sendeþ oþer wiser ambassatours
For by my trouþe me were lever die
Then I shulde you to hasardoures allie ¶
For ye þat ben so glorious in honoures
Shal not allie yo wᵗith hasardoures
As my wil / ne as bi my trete
This wise philosopher þus saide he
Loke eke þat to þe king demetrius
The king of partes as þe book saiþ þus
Sent him a peire of dees of gold in scorne
For he had vsid hasardie þer biforne
For whiche he held his glorie and his renou
For no value of reputacioıı̄un
Lordes might finde oþ̉er/re man plaie
Honest I now to dryue þe dai awaie
Now wol I speke of oþes fals and grete
A worde or too as oþer bokes entrete
Grete swering is a þing abhominable
And fals swering is miche more reprevable
The highe god forbad swering at all
Wittenes of mathu / but in especial
Ieremie 4ᵒ . Iurabis inquit in veritate īm iudicōm et iusticia
Of swering þe holi Ieromie
Þou shalt swere soþ þin oþes and not lie
And swere in dome and eke in right wisnesse
But Idel swering is a cursidnesse
Behold and se þat in þe first table
Of high goddes hestes honourable
How þat two hestes of him is þis
Take not my tale in Idelnesse a mys
Loo . raþer he forbedith suche swering
Þen homicide or any oþer þing
I sai as þus bi ordre it stondith
Þis knowiþ þat his hestes vnderstondith
How þat þe second hest of god is þat
And forþer over I wol þe telle al plat
Þat vengeaıı̄unce shal not ꝑper/parte fro his hous
Þat of his oþes is so outrageous
Bi goddis precious hert and his nailes
And bi his blood þat is in hailes
Seuene is my chaıı̄unce and his five and þre
Bi goddes armes if þou falsli plaie wᵗith me
Þis dagger shal þorugh þin hert goo
Þis fruyt comeþ of þilke bones too
For swering Ire falsnesse homicide
Now for þe loue of crist þat for vs dide
Leueþ yoᵘur oþes boþe grete and smale
For I shal telle you a merveilous tale
Þise riotours of whiche I telle
Long erst or prime rong any belle
Were sette in a tauerne to drinke
And as þei satte þei herde a belle chynke
Beforn a corps was caried to his gᵃue
Þat oon of hem gan calle to his knaue
Go bet qd he / and aske redili
What corps is þat þat passeþ forþ bi
And loke þat þou report his name wele
Sir qd þis knaue it nedeþ neủer/re adele
It was me told or ye come here too houres
He was ꝑper/parde an olde felow of youres
Al sodenly was he slain to night
For dronken as he sat vpon his benche vp right
Þer come a preuy theef men clepen deþ
Þat in his contraie al þe peple fleþ
And wᵗith his spere he smoot his hert atoo
And wente his wai wᵗithout wordes moo
He haþ a þousand slain þis pestilence
And maist̉er/re er ye come in his psence
Me þinkeþ þat it were necessarie
For to be war of suche aduersarie
Beth redi for to mete him eủer/remore
Þus taught me my dame I sai nomore
Beseint marie saide þis tauernere
Þe child saiþ soth for he haþ slayn to yere
Hens oủer/re a myle wᵗithyn agrete village
Boþ man and woman child and page
I trowe his habitaciou þere ¶þꝑper/par
To ben avised gret wisdom it were
Or þat he dide aman dishonoᵘur
Ye goddis armes qd þis riotoᵘur
Is it suche ꝑper/paril wᵗith him for to mete
I shal him seche bi stile and bi strete
I make avowe bi goddes digne bones
Herkeneþ felawes we þre ben al ones
Lete eche of vs holde vp his honde to oþer
And eche of vs be come oþer broþer
And we wil sle þis fals traitoᵘur deþ
He shal be slayn he þat so mony sleþ
By goddis dignyte er it be night
To gider han þise þre here hertes plight
To lyue and to die ilke of hem wᵗith oþer
As þough he were his owne borne broþ̉er/re
And vp þei sterten and dronken in þis rage
And forþ þei gon to ward þat village
Of whiche þe tauern haþ spoken bi forn
And mony a grisli oþe þen han þei sworn
And cristꝭes blissed bodi þei to rent
Þat þeef shal be dede if þat we mai him hent
When þei han goon not fulli a myle
Right as þei wolde haue troden oủer/re a stile
An olde pore man wiþ hem mette
This olde man ful mekeli hem grette
And saide þus . now lordes god you se
Þe proudest of þise riotours þre
Annswerd a yen what cherle wᵗith harde gᵃce
Whi art þou al forwrappid sauf þi face
Whi lyuest þou so long in so gret age
This olde man gan loke in his visage
And saide þus for I con not finde
A man þough I walked in to Inde
Neiþer in cite ne in noo village
Þat wil chaıı̄ungen his youþe for myn age
And þ̉er/refore mote I haue myn age stille
As long time as it is goddis wille
Ne deþ allas nyl not haue my lif
Thus walke I like a resteles caitif
And on þe grounde whiche is my moder gate
I knok wᵗith my staf erly and late
And sai leue moder late me Inne
Loo how I vanshe flessh blode ⁊and skynne
Allas whan shul my bones ben at reste
Moder wᵗith you wolde I chaıı̄unge my cheste
Þat in my chambre long time haþ be
Ȝe for an hier cloute to wrappe me
But yitt to me she wol not do þat gᵃce
For which ful welkid is my face
But sires to you it is no curtesie
To speke vntil an olde man vilanye
But he trespas in worde or elles in dede
In holi writ ye mai yoᵘur self wel rede
A yenst an olde man hoor vpon his hede
Ye shulde arise þerfore I yeue you rede
Ne doþ as to an olde man harme as now
Nomore þan ye wolde aman dide yow
In age if þat ye so long abide
And god be wiþ you wheþ̉er/re ye goo or ride
I mot goo þider as I haue to goo
Nai olde cherle be god þou shalt not so
Saide þise oþer hasardoᵘurs anoon
Þow partest not so lightli bi seint Iohn
Þou spak right now of þilke traitoᵘur deþ
Þat in þis contre al oure frendes sleþ
Haue here my trouþe as þou art his aspie
Telle where he is or elles þou shalt die
Bi god and bi þe holi sacrament
For soþli þou art of his assent
To slen vs yong folk þou fals þef
Now sirs if it be to you so lef
To finde deþ tʳne vp þis crokid wai ¶þꝑper/par
For in þat groue I left him bi my wai
Vnder a tre and þer he wol a bide
Ne for yoᵘur bost he nyl him noþing hide
See ye þat oke right þer ye shal him finde
God saue you þat bought ayen mankynde

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth Chaucers tale of Melibeus

(base) A yong man whilom called Melibeus myghty and
riche bigat vp on his wif that called was Prudence a
doghter which that called was Sophie

(base) vp on a day bifel that
he for his desport is went in to the feeldes hym to pleye

(base) his
wif and eek his doghter hath he laft inwith his hous of which
the dores weren faste yshette
(base) thre of his olde foos han it espied and setten laddres to the walles of his hous and by wyndowes ben entred

(base) and betten his wif and wounded his doghter with
fyue mortal woundes in fyue sondry places

(base) this is to seyn
in hir feet in hir handes in hir erys in hir nose and in hir
mouth and leften hire for deed and wenten awey

(base) Whan Melibeus retourned was in to his hous and seigh al this meschief he
lyk a mad man rentynge his clothes gan to wepe and crye

(base) Prudence his wyf as ferforth as she dorste bisoughte hym of
his wepyng for to stynte

(base) but nat for thy he gan to crye and
wepen euere lenger the moore

(base) This noble wif Prudence
remembred hire vp on the sentence of Ouyde in his book that
cleped is the remedie of loue wher as he seith

(base) he is a fool
that destourbeth the moder to wepe in the deth of hir child
til she haue wept hir fille as for a certeyn tyme

(base) and thanne
shal man doon his diligence with amyable wordes hire to reconforte and preye hire of hir wepyng for to stynte

(base) for which
reson this noble wyf Pru

(base) for sothe it aperteneth nat to a wys man to maken swich a sorwe

(base) yowre

(base) And al were it so that she right now were deed ye ne oghte nat as

(base) Prudence

div.l: As Adam til he for his mysgoủer/renaıı̄unce
Was dryue out of high prosꝑper/parite
To laboᵘur . and to helle and to myschaıı̄unce
Loo Sampson þat was anunciate
Be þe angel longe er his natuite
And was to god almighti consecrate
And stood in nobles . while þat he might se
Was neue siche anoþ̉er/re as was he
To speke of strengþe and þerto hardynesse
But to his wifes . to wifes tolde he his secre
Þurgh which he slough him silf for wrecchidnesse
Thre hundrit foxis took Sampson for Ire
And alle her tailes he togider bonde
And sette þe foxis tailis on fyre
For he in euery tail haþ knyt a bronde
And þai brent alle þe cornes of þat londe
And alle her Olyuers and vynes eke
And þousand men he slough eke wᵗith his honde
And had no wepen but an asses cheke
Whan þai were slain so þursted him þat he
Was wel nere lorn / for whiche gan to praie
Þat god of his paine haue som pite
And sende him drinke and elles most he die
And out of his assis cheke þat was so drie
Out of a woungetoth sprong anon a welle
Of whiche he dronke I nowe shortli to saie
Þus help him god . as Iudicum can telle
BI verrai force . of . Algason on a night
Maugre þe Philistiens . of þat cite
Þat gates of þat toun . he haþ vpplight
And on his bac caried hem haþ he
High vpon an hille . where men might hem se
O . noble mighti Sampsoıı̄un . leue and dere
Haddest þou not to wymmēm tolde þi secre
In all þe world . ne hadde be þi pere
This Sampson neiþ̉er/re siser . dronke ne wyne
Ne on his hede com raser noon ne non shere
Bi precept of þe messanger diuine
For alle þe strengþe in his heris were
And fulli twenti wynter yere bi yere
He had of Ierusalem . þe gouernaıı̄unce
But sone he shal wepe many a tere
For wymen shul him bringe to myschaıı̄unce
Unto his lemma Dalida he tolde
Þat in his heris al his strengþe lai
And falsli to his fomen . she him solde
And sleping in hir barm vpōmn a dai
She made to clippe . or shere his heris awai
And made his fomen al his craft espien
And when þei fonde him in þis arrai
Þei bonde him fast / and pit out boþe his eien
Bot or his heer clipped was or shaue
Þer was no bande wiþ whiche mēm might hīm bynde
But now is he in prisoıı̄un in a caue
Þer as þei made him to þe querne grinde
O . noble Sampson . strengist of al māmkynde
O . whilom Iuge in glori and in richesse
Now maistow wepe wᵗith þin eien blinde
Siþ þou fro wele art falle into wrecchidnesse
The ende of þis caitif was as I shal sai
His fomen made a fest vpon a dai
And made him as her fool . biforn hem plai
And þis was in a temple of gret arrai
But atte last he made a foul affrai
For he too pilers shook / and made hēm falle
And doıı̄unn fel temple and al and þ̉er/re it lai
And slough him self and eke his fomen alle
This is to sain þe princes eủer/reychoıı̄un
And eke þre þousand bodies wer þ̉er/re slain
Wiþ falling of þe gret temple of stoıı̄un
Of Sampson wol I nomore sain
Bewar bi þese ensamples olde ⁊and plain
Þat noman telle his counseil to his wif
Of siche þing as he wolde haue secre fain
If þat it touche his limes or his lif
OF hercules / ; þe souerein conqueroᵘur /
Singing his werkes laude and high renoıı̄un
For in his time of strengþe he bar þe floᵘur /
He slough and raft þe skyn fro þe liou

Þe gold . appel . he raft fro þe dragoıı̄un

And made his hors to frete him flessh and bon

For al þis world for drede of him haþ quaked
He was of knighthode and of fredam floure
Fortune him made þe heire . of her honoure
Saue wyn and wymen . noþing might aswage
His hie entent . in armes and in laboure
So was he ful of lumyne corage
What pite were it to him þough I you tolde
Of darius . and an hundrit þousand moo
Of kinges . princes . dukes . and erles bolde
Whiche he conquerid . and brought to woo
I sai as fer as men mai ride or goo
The world was his what shold I more deuise
Of his knighthode it might not suffise
Twelue yeer he regned as saiþ Machabe
Philippes son of macedon he was
Þat first was king in Grece þat contre
O . worþi gentil Alisaundre alas
Þat euere shulde falle suche a cas
Empoisound of þine owne folk / þou were
Þin fortune . is torned . in to an aas
And right for þe . ne wept she neủer/ree a tere
Who shal men þeuēm teris to compleyne
Þe deþ of gentils / and of Fraunchise
Þat al þe worlde had in his demaigne
And yitt him þought / it might not suffise
So ful was his corage . of hie emprise
Alas who shal helpe . me to endite
Fals fortune . and pisoun to despise
Þe whiche / too al þis woo I wite
By wisdom manhod and gret laboᵘur
Fro humble bed to roial mageste
Vp roos he Iulius þe conqueroᵘur
Þat whan al þe occident bi lande and se
Bi strengþe of honde or ellis bi trete
And vnto rome made him contributorie
And sith of Rome þemꝑper/parour was he
Til þat fortune wex his aduersarie
O mighti Cesar . þat in Thessalie
Agains Pompious . fader þin in lawe
Þat of þe orient had al þe cheualrie
Als fer as þat þe dai . begynnes to dawe
Þurgh þine knighthode þou hast him take ⁊and slawe
Saue fewe folk þat wiþ pompous fledde
Þurgh whiche þou pittist al þe orient in awe
Þanke fortune . þat þoo wel þe spedde
But now a litil while I wil be waile
Þis pompous þe noble gouernoᵘur
Of rome whiche þat flawe fro þis bataile
Alas I sai on of his men . a fals traitoᵘur
His hede of smot . to wynne his fauoᵘur
Of Iulius . and him þe hede he brought
Alas pomp . of þe orient conqueroᵘur
Þat fortune to suche a fam þe brought
TO Rome again repaireþ Iulius
Wiþ his triumphe laureat ful hie
But on a time Brutus Cassius
Þat eue hadde on his state envie
Ful priuely haþ made conspiracie
Agains þis Iulius in subtil wise
Cast þe place in whiche he shulde die
Wiþ Boidekyns . as I shal you deuise
This Iulius . to þe Capitoil went
Vpon a dai as he was wont to gon
And in þe Capitoil anoon him hent
Þis fals brutus / and his oþ̉er/re fon
And stiked him wᵗith . boidekyns anon
Wiþ many wounde . and þus þei let him lie
But neue gront / he at no strok but on
Or ellis at too / but if þe storie lie
SO manli was þis Iulius of hert
And so wel loued estatli honeste
Þat þough his dedli woundes so sore smert
His mantil oue his hipes cast he
For noman shulde seen his priuete
And he lai dieng on atraunce
And wist þat verreli ded was he
Of honeste yett hadde he remēmbraıı̄unce
Lucan to þe . þis stori I recōmmaıı̄unde
And to Sweton . and to valerian . also
Þat al þe stori writen worde and ende
How to þese grete conquerours too
Fortune was first frende and sithen foo
Noman trust vpon hir fauoᵘur longe
But haue hir in a wait for eue moo
Wittenesse on all þese conqueroᵘurs stronge
OF riche Gresus whilom king of lide
Off whiche gresus . Cirus him sore dradde
Yett was he caught amyddes al his pride
And to þe fuyr to brenne him . men hīm ladde
But siche arayn doun from þe heuen shadde
Þat slough þe fuyr / and made him to escape
But to be war yett grace noon he hadde
Til fortune on þe galous made him gape
Whan he was escapid . he couþe not stent
For to begynne a newe werre agayn
He wende wel for þat fortune him sent
Siche hap . þat he escapid þurgh þe rayn
Þat of his foos . he might not be slayn
And eeke a sweuen vpon a night he mette
Of whiche he was so proude and eke so fayn
Þat in vengeaıı̄unce he al his hert . sette
Upon a tre . he was as him þought
Wher Iubiter him wasshe . boþe bac . and side
And phebus eke . and fair towel him brought
To drie him wiþ and herfore wex his pride
And to his doughter þat stood him beside
Whiche þat he knew in hie science habounde
And bad her telle . what it signyfied
And she his dreme . right þus gan expounde
The tre qd . she . þe galous is to mene
And Iubiter likenith snow and rayn
And phebus wiþ his towaile so clene
To ben þe sonne stremes soþ to sayn
Þou shalt enhangit ben fadir certayn
Rayn shal þe wasshe / and sonne shal þe drie
Þus warnid she him / ful plat / and eke ful playn
His doughtir / whiche þat callit was phanie
And hanged was gresus . þis proude king
His real tour . might him not auaile
Tregedis . ne noon oþer maner þing
Ne can in singing crie . ne biwaile
Bot for þat fortune . wil alday assaile
Wiþ vnwar strok / þe regnes þat ben proude
For when trustiþ her / þen wil she faile
And couer her bright face . wiþ a cloude
Here endeþ þe monkes tale

l.hi: Here begynneþ þe prolog of þe nōmne prestꝭes tale of þe cok /
and of þe henne .

div.l: HO sire qd þe knight nomore of þis
Þat ye han said is right I nough I wis
And mychel more / for litel heuynes
Is right I nough . for mikel folk I ges
I sai for me it is a gret disese
Wher as men han ben in gret welþe and ese
To heren of . her sodeyn fal . alas
And þe contrarie is ioie and gret solas
As whan a man haþ ben in poer estate
And clymbeþ vp . and wexiþ fortunate
And þere abideþ in prosꝑper/parite
Suche þing is gladsom as þinkes me
And of siche þinge were goodli for to telle
Ye quod oure . host / bi seint Poules belle
Ye sai right soþ . þis monk haþ clappid loude
He spak how fortune was clippid wiþ a cloude
I not neủer/ree . what and also of tregedie
Right now . þe herde and parde non remedie
It is for to bewaile or complayne
Þat . þat is don and also . it is a payne
As ye han said to hire of heuynesse
Sire monk no more of þis so god yoᵘur soule blesse
Youre tale annoyeth al þis companye
Siche taling is not worþ a boterflie
For þerinne is non desport ne game
Wherfore sir monk dain . peris bi yoᵘur name
I pᵃie you hertli telle vs sumwhat ellis
For sicurli ner ginking of þe bellis
Þat on youre bridel honge on euery side
Be heuen king þat for vs alle dide
I shulde er þis haue falle doun for slepe
Al þough þe slough . had neủer/ree be so depe
Þan had youre tale . al be invayn
For certeinli as þese clerkꝭes sayn
Where as a man may haue noon audience
Nought helpiþ it to tellen his sentence
And wel I woot þe substaunce is in me
If any þing shal wel reportid be
Sir sai somwhat of hunting I you pᵃie
Nai qd þe monk I haue no lust to plaie
Now let a noþer telle as I haue tolde
Þan spak oure host wiþ rude speche and bold
And saide vnto þe nonnes prest anoon
Come neer þou prest . come neer þou Iohn
Telle vs suche þing as mai oure hert glade
Be bliþe þough þou ride vpon a iade
What þough þin hors be boþe foule and lene
If he wol serue recche not a bene ¶þe nōmne prest .
Loke þat þin hert be mery eủer/re moo
Yes sir . yes . host as mot I goo
But I be mery / I wis I wil be blamid
And right anon he haþ his tale tamid
And þus he saide vn to vs eủer/rey chone
Þis swete prest þis goodli man sir Iohne

l.hi: Ere begynneþ þe nōmne prestꝭes tale

div.l: A pore widow somdel stope in age
Was whilom duelling in a pore cotage
Beside a groue stonding in a dale
Þis widow of which I telle you my tale
Syn þilke dai þat she was last a wif
In pacience lad . a ful simple lif
For litil was hir catel and hir rent
Bi husbandri . of swiche as god hir sent
She fond hir silf and eke hir doughtryn too
Þre large sowes had she and no moo
Þre kien and eke a shep / þat hight malle
Ful soti was hir boure and eke hir halle
In whiche she eete . ful many a sklender mele
Of poynaund sauce / hir nedit neủer/re a deel
No deynte morcel passid þurgh hir þrote
Hir diete was accordint to hir cote
Replecioun made hir neủer/ree sike
Attempre diete . was al hire phisike
And excercise and hertis suffisaunce
Þe goute lette hir noþing for to daıı̄unce
Napoplexie . shent not hir hede
No wyn dronk she neiþ̉er/re white ne rede
Hire borde seruid boþe wiþ white and blak
Mylk and broun bred in whiche fonde she no lak /
Seyn bacoun . and som time an eie or tweie
For she was as it were a maner deie
A yerde she had enclosid al aboute
Wiþ stikkis / and a drie diche withoute
In whiche she hadde a cok / þat hight chauntclere
In all þe lande of crowyng was noon his pere
His vois was merier þan þe mery orgon
On masse daies þat in the chirche gon
Wel sikerir was his crowyng in his logge
Þan is a cloc / or an abbey orologge
Bi nature he knew iche ascencioıı̄un
Of equinoxial in þilk / toun
For whanne degrees fiftene were ascendit
Þan krew he it might not ben amendit /
His comb . was radder / þen þe fin coral
And batailed as it were a castel wal
His bil was blak / and as þe get it shon
Lik asure were his leggis / and his ton
His nailes whitter þen þe lili floure
And lik þe burnysshed gold was his coloᵘur
Þis gentil cok hadde in his gouernaıı̄unce
Seuene hennes . for to don al his plesaıı̄unce
Whiche were his sustres and his ꝑper/paramoures
And wonder lik to him / as of coloures
Of whiche þe fairest hewed on þe þrote
Was clepud faire damesel pertelote
Curteis she was discrete and debonaire
And compenable and bar hirsilf ful faire
Syn þilke dai þat she was seuen yere olde
Þat she haþ truli þe hert in holde
Of chauntclere lokyn in eủer/rey lith /
He louid hir so . þat wele was him þerwith
But siche a ioie was it to hire him singe
Whan þat þe bright sonne began to springe
In swete accord my leef is faren on londe
Fro þilke time as I haue vnderstonde
Bestis and briddes coude speke and singe
And so bifel / þat in a dawynge
As chauntclere amongꝭes his wyues alle
Sat on his perche þat was on his halle
And next him sat this faire pertelote ¶Þe nōmne prest
Þis chauntclere gan gronen in his þrote
As man þat in his dreem is drecchid sore
And whan þat Pertelot þus herde him rore
She was agast / and saide hert dere
What eileþ you to grone in þis mane
Ye ben a verrey sleper fie for shame
And he aunswerd and saide þus madame
I pᵃie you þat ye take it nat a gref
Bi god me mette I was in siche mischef
Right now þat yitt my hert is sore afright
Now god qd he my sweuen reche aright
And kepe my bodi out of foule prisoıı̄un
Me mette how þat I romed vp and doıı̄unn
Wiþinne oure yerde where as I saw a best /
Was lik / an hounde and wolde haue made arest
Vpon my bodi and wolde han had me dede
His coloᵘur was betwixt yollow and rede
And tipped was his tail and boþe his eris
Wiþ blac vnlik þe remenāmt of his heris
His snowte was smal wᵗith glowyng eien tweie
Yett of his look for feer al most I deie
Þis causid me my gronyng douteles
Awai . qd she . fie on you hertles
Alas qd she / for bi þat god aboue
Now haue ye lost my hert and al my loue
I cannot loue a coward / bi my faiþe
For certes what so any womman saiþe
We alle desiren if it might be
To haue husbondes hardi riche and fre
And secre ne non nigard / ne fool
Ne him þat is a gast of eủer/rey tool
Ne non auauntere bi þat god aboue
How durst ye sain for shame vnto yoᵘur loue
Þat any þing might make you a ferde
Haue ye no mannes hert and haue a berde
Alas and can ye ben agast for sweuens
Nought god woot but vanite in sweuens is .
Sweuens engendred be of replexioıı̄uns
And often of fume and of complexioıı̄uns
Whan humoᵘurs ben to habundant in awight
Certis þis drem . whiche ye han met to night
Comeþ of þe grete suꝑper/parfluite
Of youre rede colora ꝑper/parde .
Whiche causiþ folke to dreme in hir dremes
Of arwes . and of fuyr / wᵗith rede bemes
Of rede bestis þat þai wil him bite
Of contek / and of whelpis / grete and lite
Right as þe humoᵘur of malencolie
Causeþ in sleep ful many man to crie
For feer of beris or of boles blake
Or ellis blak deuels wol hem take
Off oþer humours couþe I telle also
Þat wirken many man in sleep ful woo
But I wol passe as lightli as I can
Lo catou whiche þat was so wis aman
Seide he not þus . ne do no fors of dremis
Now sire qd she whan we fle fro þise bemis
For goddes loue as take som laxatif
Vp peril of my soule and of my lif
I coıı̄unseil you þe best I wol not lie
Þough in þis toıı̄un is non appotecarie
I shal my self too herbes teche you
Þat shul be for youre hele and for yoᵘur prow
And in oure yerde þoo erbes shal I finde
Þe whiche han of hir ꝓpropurte bi kynde
To purgen you bi neþe and eke aboue
For yete not þis for goddes owne loue
Ye ben ful colorik / of complexioıı̄un
War þe sonne in his ascencioıı̄un
Ne finde you not replete in humoᵘurs hote
And if it do / I dar wel lai a grote
Þat ye shul haue a feuer terciane
Or an agew . þat mai be yoᵘur bane
A daie or too ye shal haue digestiues ¶Þe nōmne prest .
Of wormes er ye take laxatiues
Of laureal Centaure . and fumitere
Or ellis of elderberi þat growiþ þere
Of catapus . or of gaitre berijs
Of herbe Iue . þat growiþ in oure ȝerde þ̉er/re meri is
Picke hem vp right / as þei growe . and ete hem In
Be mery husbond for yoᵘur fader kyn .
Dredeþ no drem I can sei nomore
Madame qd he graunt mercy of youre lore
But naþeles as touching dan Catoun
Þat haþ of wisdom siche a high renou
Þough þat he bad no dremes for to drede
Bigod men mai in olde bokes rede
Of many man . more of auctorite
Þan eủer/ree Catoıı̄un was so mot I þe
Þat al þe reuers sain . of his sentence
And han wel founden bi exꝑper/parience
Þat dremes ben significacions
Aswel of ioie as of tribulacioıı̄uns
Þat folk enduren in þis lif present
Þere nediþ make of þis noon argument
Þe verrey preue shewiþ it in dede
Oon of þe grettist auctorite þat men rede
Saiþ þus . þat whilom twaie felous wente
On pilgrimage . in a ful good entente
And happid so thei come In a toun
Where as þer was siche congregacioıı̄un
Of people . and eke so streite of herborgage
Þat þei fonde not as moche as on cotage
In whiche þat þei might boþe I loggit be
Wherfore þei most of necessite
As for þat night depart her companie
And eche of hem goþ to his hostilrie
And took / his logging / as it wolde falle
Þat oon of hem was loggid in a stalle
Ferre in a yerde wᵗith oxen of þe plough
Þat oþer man was loggit wel ynough
As was his aduenture or fortune
Þat vs gouernes alle in comune
And so bifel þat long er it were dai
Þis on met . in his bed . there as he lai
How þat his felaw gan vpon him calle
And saide alas . for in an oxe stalle
Þis night I shal be murdrit þ̉er/ree I lie
Now helpe me dere broþ̉er/re or I die
In alle hast come to me he saide
Þis man out of his slep . for fere abraide
But whan he was waked out of his slepe
He tʳned him / and took of þis no kepe
Him þought his drem nas but a vanite
Þus twies in his slepe dremed he
And atte þe þirde time yitt his felawe
Cam as him þought and saide I am now slawe
Beholde my blodi woundes depe ⁊and wide
Arise vp erli in þe morow tide
And atte westgate of þe toun qd he
A cart of donge . þere shalt þou se
In whiche my bodi is hid priueli
Do þilke cart arestin boldeli
Mi gold causid my mʳder soþ to sain
And tolde him eủer/rey point how he was slain
Wiþ a ful pitous face pale of hewe
And trust wel his drem he fonde ful trewe
For on þe morow as sone as it was daie
To his felaws In / he took / þe waie
And whan þat he cam to his Oxe stalle
Aftir his felaw he bigan to calle
Þe Hostiler aunswerid him anoon
And saide sir youre felaw is goon
As sone as dai he went out of þe toun
Þis man gan falle in suspecioıı̄un
Remembring in his dremes þat he mette
And forþ he goþ . no lenger wolde he lette
Vn to þe westgate / of þe toun and fonde ¶Þe nōmne prest
A donge cart went as it were to donge londe
Þat was arraied in þe same wise
As ye han herde þe dede man deuise
And wiþ an hardi hert he gan to crie
Vengeaunce and Iustice of þis felonie
Mi felaw murdrit is þis same night
And in þis cart here he lith vpright
I crie out on þe ministers qd he
Þat shulde kepe and rewel þis cite
Harrow . alas . here lithe my felaw slayn
What shulde I more vnto his tale sain
Þe peple vp stert / and kest þe cart to grounde
And in þe midde of þe donge þei founde
Þe dede man þat murdred was al newe
O . blisful god þou art ful Iust and trewe
Loo . how þou bewriest murder al dai
Murder wol out . it is no nay
Murder is so lothsom . and abhominable
To god . þat is so iust and resonable
Þat he ne wolde not suffre it helid be
Þough it abide a yere . or too . or þre
Mordre wol out þis is my conclusioıı̄un
And right anoon þe ministirs of þat toun
Han hent þe carter and so sore hym pyned
And eke þe Hostiler so sore engined
Þat þei beknew hir wickednes anoon
And were an honget bi þe necke bon
Here men mai se þat dremes ben to drede
And certes in þe same book / I rede
Right in þe next Chapitre aftir þis
I gabbe not so haue I ioie or blisse
Too men þat wolde haue passed ouer þe se
For certein causes into a ferre contre
If þat þe wynde ne had be contrarie
Þat made hem in a cite for to tarie
Þat stode ful mery vpon an hauen side
But on a dai . again þe euen tide .
Þe wynde gan chaunge . and right as hem lest
Iolif and glad . þei went vn to rest
And cast hem ful erli for to saile
But herkenith to þat oon . man . fel agret meruaile
Þat oon of hem sleping as he lai
Him mette a wonder dreme agayn þe dai
Him þought aman stood bi his beddes side
And cōmmaundit þat he shuld abide
And saide him þus if þou to morow wende
Þou shalt be dreint my tale is at an ende
He wook / and tolde his felaw what he mette
And pᵃied him his viage to lette
As for þat dai he pᵃiede him to abide
His felaw þat lai bi his beddes side
Gan for to laugh and scornid him ful fast
No drem qd he mai so my herte gaste
Þat I wol lette for to doo my þinges
I sette not a straw / bi þi dremynges
For sweuens ben but vanitees and Iapes
Men dreme al dai of owles and of apes
And of many a mase þerwiþal
Men dreme of þinges þat neủer/ree be shal
But sith I se þat þou wolt here abide
And þus forslouþe wilfilli þi tide
God wot it rewiþ me and haue good dai
And þus he took / his leue and went his wai
But er he had half his cours sailid
Not I not whi . ne what meschaıı̄unce it ailid
But casuelli þe shippes bothom rent
And ship and man vnder þe water went
In sight of oþer shippes beside
Þat wiþ him sailid at þe same tide
And þerfore faire Pertelot so dere
Bi siche ensamples olde mai þou lere
Þat noman shuld be to reches .
Of dremes . for I sai þe douteles
Þat many a drem ful sore is for to drede ¶Þe nōmne prest
Loo in þe lif of seint Kenelme I rede
Þat was kenulphus son þat noble Kinge
Of mertinrike . how kenelme mette þinge
A litil he was murdrit vpon adai
His murdre in his auision he sai
His norice . him expouned eủer/reydel
His sweuen and bad him for to kepe him wel
For traison / but he nas but seuen yeer olde
And therfore litil tale haþ he tolde
Of any dreme / so holi was his hert /
Bi god I had leuer þan my shert /
Þᵗat ye had red his legende as haue I
Dame Pertelot I sai you truli
Macrobius þat writ þe avisioıı̄un
In auffrik of þe worþi Cipioun
Affermeþ dremes and saiþ þat þei been
Warnīmg of þinges . þat men aftir seen
And forþermore I pᵃy you lokiþ wel
In þe olde testament of Daniel
If he hulde dremes any vanite
Rede eke of Ioseph and þere shal ye se
Wheþir dremes ben somtime I sai not alle
Warning of þinges þat shul aftir falle
Loke of Egipt þe king dain pharao
His baker and his botiler also

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth the Persons tale

(base) Iere 6ᵒ State super vias et videte et interrogate de semitis
antiquis que sit via bona et ambulate in ea et inuenietis refrigerium animabus vestris et cetera

(base) Ovre swete lord god of heuene that no man wole
perisse but wole that we comen alle to the kNoweliche
of hym and to the blisful lyf that is pardurable
(base) amonesteth vs by the prophete Ieromie that seith in this wise

(base) Stondeth vp on the weyes and seeth and axeth of olde pathes that is to seyn of olde sentences which is the goode
wey
(base) and walketh in that wey and ye shal fynde refresshynge for youre soules et cetera

(base) Manye been the weyes espirituels that leden folk to oure lord Ihesu crist and to the regne
of glorie

(base) of whiche weyes ther is a ful noble wey and
a ful couenable which may nat faile to man ne to womman that thurgh synne hath mysgoon fro the righte wey
of Ierusalem celestial

(base) and this wey is clepid Penitence
of which men sholde gladly herknen and enquere with al
his herte

(base) to wite what is penitence and whennes it is
clepid penitence and in how manye maneres been the accions
or werkynges of penitence

(base) and how manye spices ther
ben of penitences and whiche thynges apertenen and bihouen to penitence whiche thynges destourben penitence

(base) Seint Ambrose seith that penitence is the pleynynge of
man for the gilt that he hath doon and namoore to doon
any thyng for which hym oghte to pleyne

(base) And som dectour seith Penitence is the waymentynge of man that sorweth for his synne and pyneth hym self for he hath
mysdoon

(base) Penitence with certeyne circumstances is verray
repentance of a man that halt hym self in sorwe and oother
peyne for hise giltes

(base) and for he shal be verray penitent
he shal first biwailen the synnes that he hath doon and
stedefastly purposen in his herte to haue shrift of mouthe
and to doon satisfaccioun

(base) and neuere to doon thyng for which
hym oghte moore to biwaile or to compleyne and to continue in goode werkes or ellis his repentance may nat auayle

(base) For as seith Seint Isydre he is a Iapere and

tyme that man falleth be it neuer so ofte that he may arise thurgh
penitence if he haue grace but certeynly it is greet dowithe

(base) and
Now sith that I haue declared yow what thyng is penitence
Now shul ye vnderstonde that ther been iij accions of penitence
(base) The firste is that if a man be baptised after that he hath synned

(base) Seint
Augustyn seith but he be penitent for his olde synful lyf he may
nat bigynne the newe clene lyf

(base) for certes if he be baptised with
oute penitence of his olde gilt he receyueth the mark of baptesme but nat the grace ne the remissioun of hise synnes til he haue repentance verray

(base) Another defaute is this that men doon
deedly synne after that they han receyued baptesme

(base) The
thridde defaute is that men fallen in venyal synnes after
hire baptesme fro day to day

(base) ther of seith Seint Augustyn
That penitence of goode and of humble folk is the penitence
of euery day

(base) The speces of penaunce been iij that oon of
hem is solempne Another is commune and the thridde is priuee

(base) Thilke penaunce that is solempne is in two maneres as
to be put out of holy chirche in lente for slaughtre of children
and swich manere thyng

(base) Another is whan man hath synned
openly of which synne the fame is openly spoken in the contree
and thanne holy chirche by Iugement destreyneth hym for to
doon open penance

(base) Commune penaunce is that preestes enioynen
men communly in certeyn cas as for to goon parauenture naked in
pilgrymage or barefoot

(base) Pryuee penaunce is thilke that men
doon al day for priuee synnes of whiche we shryue vs pryuely
and receyue pryuee penance

(base) Now shaltow vnderstande
what bihoueth and is necessarie to verray parfit penitence and
this stant on iij thynges

(base) Contricioun of herte Confessioun of
Mouth and Satisfaccioun

(base) for which seith Seint Iohn Grisostomus
Penitence destreyneth man to accepte benygnely euery peyne that hym
is enioyned with contricioun of herte and shrift of Mowithhe with satisfaccioun and in wirkynge of alle manere humylitee

(base) and this is
fruytful penitence agayn iij thynges in whiche we wrathe oure
lord Ihesu crist
(base) this is to seyn by delit in thynkynge by recchelesnesse in spekynge by wikked synful wirkynge

(base) and agayns
thise wikkede giltes is penitence that may be likned vn to a tree

(base) The roote of this tree is contricioun that hideth hym in the herte of
hym that is verray repentant right as the roote of a tree hideth
hym in the erthe

(base) Of the roote of Contricioun spryngeth a stalke
that bereth branches and leues of confessioun and fruyt of satisfaccioun

(base) for which crist seith in his gospel dooth digne fruyt
of penitence for by this fruyt may men kNowe this tree and
nat by the roote that is hyd in the herte of man ne by the branches ne the leues of Confessioun

(base) And therfore oure Lord Ihesu crist
seith thus by the fruyt of hem shul ye kNowe hem

(base) Of this
roote eek spryngeth a Seed of grace the which Seed is moder
of Sikernesse and this Seed is egre and hoot

(base) the grace of thys
Seed spryngeth of god thurgh remembrance on the day of dome
and on the peynes of helle

(base) Of this matere seith Salomon that
in the drede of god man forleteth his synne

(base) the hete of thys
seed is the loue of god and the desirynge of the Ioye pardurable

(base) this hete draweth the herte of man to god and dooth hym hate
his synne

(base) for soothly ther is no thyng that sauoureth so wel
to a child as the mylk of his norice ne no thyng is to hym
moore abhomynable than thilke mylk whan it is medled with
oother mete

(base) right so the synful man that loueth his synne

(base) but fro that

(base) for soothly the lawe of god is the loue of god for which
Dauid the prophete seith I haue loued thy lawe and hated wikkednesse and hate he that loueth god kepeth his lawe and his word

in this manere as seith Seint Bernard It shal ben heuy and
